author: WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE
content: orphans late made trees mountain tops freeze bow sing music plants flowers ever sprung sun shower made lasting spring every thing heard play even pillows sea hung heads lay sweet music art killing care grief heart fall asleep hearing die
poem name: Song: Orpheus with his lute made trees
ori_content:
Orpheus with his lute made trees, 
And the mountain tops that freeze, 
Bow themselves when he did sing:
To his music plants and flowers 
Ever sprung; as sun and showers 
There had made a lasting spring. 
Every thing that heard him play, 
Even the billows of the sea, 
Hung their heads, and then lay by. 
In sweet music is such art, 
Killing care and grief of heart 
Fall asleep, or hearing, die.
con: orphan late made tree mountain top freeze bow sing music plant flower ever sprung sun shower made lasting spring every thing heard play even pillow sea hung head lay sweet music art killing care grief heart fall asleep hearing die

author: WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE
content: greenwood tree loves lie turn merry note unto sweet birds throat come hither come hither come hither shall see enemy winter rough weather doth ambition shun loves live sun seeking food eats pleased gets come hither come hither come hither shall see enemy winter rough weather
ori_content:
Under the greenwood tree
Who loves to lie with me,
And turn his merry note
Unto the sweet bird's throat,
Come hither, come hither, come hither:
            Here shall he see
            No enemy
But winter and rough weather.

Who doth ambition shun
And loves to live i' the sun,
Seeking the food he eats,
And pleased with what he gets,
Come hither, come hither, come hither:
            Here shall he see
            No enemy
But winter and rough weather.
con: greenwood tree love lie turn merry note unto sweet bird throat come hither come hither come hither shall see enemy winter rough weather doth ambition shun love live sun seeking food eats pleased get come hither come hither come hither shall see enemy winter rough weather

author: WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE
content: like winter hath absence thee pleasure fleeting year freezing felt dark days seen old december baseness everywhere yet time removed summer time seeming autumn big rich increase bearing wanton prime like widow bombs lords decease yet abundant issue seemed hope orphans unfatherd fruit summer pleasures wait thee thou away birds mute sing tis dull cheer leaves look pale dreading winters near
poem name: Sonnet 97: How like a winter hath my absence been
ori_content:
How like a winter hath my absence been
From thee, the pleasure of the fleeting year!
What freezings have I felt, what dark days seen!
What old December's bareness everywhere!
And yet this time remov'd was summer's time,
The teeming autumn, big with rich increase,
Bearing the wanton burthen of the prime,
Like widow'd wombs after their lords' decease:
Yet this abundant issue seem'd to me
But hope of orphans and unfather'd fruit;
For summer and his pleasures wait on thee,
And thou away, the very birds are mute;
Or if they sing, 'tis with so dull a cheer
That leaves look pale, dreading the winter's near.
con: like winter hath absence thee pleasure fleeting year freezing felt dark day seen old december baseness everywhere yet time removed summer time seeming autumn big rich increase bearing wanton prime like widow bomb lord decease yet abundant issue seemed hope orphan unfatherd fruit summer pleasure wait thee thou away bird mute sing ti dull cheer leaf look pale dreading winter near

author: WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE
content: didst thou promise beauteous day make travel forth without cloak let base clouds overtake way hiding thy bravery rotten smoke tis enough cloud thou break dry rain stormbeaten face man well salve speak heals wound cures disgrace thy shame give physics grief though thou repent yet still loss offenders sorrow lends weak relief bears strong offences cross ah tears pearl thy love sheds rich ransom ill deeds
poem name: Sonnet 34: Why didst thou promise such a beauteous day
ori_content:
Why didst thou promise such a beauteous day,
And make me travel forth without my cloak,
To let base clouds oertake me in my way,
Hiding thy bravery in their rotten smoke?
Tis not enough that through the cloud thou break,
To dry the rain on my storm-beaten face,
For no man well of such a salve can speak
That heals the wound and cures not the disgrace:
Nor can thy shame give physic to my grief;
Though thou repent, yet I have still the loss:
The offenders sorrow lends but weak relief
To him that bears the strong offences cross.
   Ah! but those tears are pearl which thy love sheds,
   And they are rich and ransom all ill deeds.
con: didst thou promise beauteous day make travel forth without cloak let base cloud overtake way hiding thy bravery rotten smoke ti enough cloud thou break dry rain stormbeaten face man well salve speak heals wound cure disgrace thy shame give physic grief though thou repent yet still loss offender sorrow lends weak relief bear strong offence cross ah tear pearl thy love shed rich ransom ill deed

author: WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE
content: aught bore canopy externa outward honoring laid great bases eternity proves short waste ruining seen dwellers form favour lose paying much rent compound sweet forging simple favour pitiful rivers gazing spent obsequious thy heart take thou relation poor free mind seconds knows art mutual render thee hence thou subornd informer true soul impeached stands least thy control
poem name: Sonnet 125: Weret aught to me I bore the canopy
ori_content:
Weret aught to me I bore the canopy,
With my extern the outward honouring,
Or laid great bases for eternity,
Which proves more short than waste or ruining;
Have I not seen dwellers on form and favour
Lose all, and more, by paying too much rent,
For compound sweet forgoing simple savour,
Pitiful thrivers, in their gazing spent?
No;let me be obsequious in thy heart,
And take thou my oblation, poor but free,
Which is not mixd with seconds, knows no art,
But mutual render, only me for thee.
   Hence, thou subornd informer! a true soul,
   When most impeachd, stands least in thy control.
con: aught bore canopy externa outward honoring laid great base eternity prof short waste ruining seen dweller form favour lose paying much rent compound sweet forging simple favour pitiful river gazing spent obsequious thy heart take thou relation poor free mind second know art mutual render thee hence thou subornd informer true soul impeached stand least thy control

author: WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE
content: let bird loudest lay sole arabian tree herald sad trumpet whose sound chaste wings obey thou shrieking harbingers foul recurred fiend augury fevers end troop come thou near session intersect every fowl tyrant wing save eagle feather king keep obsequy strict let priest surpliced white defective music deathdivining swan lest required lack right thou trebledated crow thy sable gender mast breath thou gist take amongst corners shalt thou go doth commence love constancy dead phoenix turtle fled mutual flame hence love love twain essence one two distinct division none number love slain hearts remote yet asunder distance space seen twist turtle queen wonder love shine turtle saw right flaming phoenix sight either others mine property thus appalled self single natures double name neither two one called reason confounded saw division grow together yet either neither simple well compound cried true twain seemed concordant one love reason reason none parts remain whereupon made three phoenix dove cosupremes stars love chorus tragic scene threads beauty truth rarity grace simplicity enclosed hinders lie death phoenix nest turtle loyal breast eternity doth rest leaving posterity twas infirmity married hastily truth may seem cannot beauty brag tis truth beauty buried turn let repair either true fair dead birds sigh prayer
ori_content:
Let the bird of loudest lay
On the sole Arabian tree
Herald sad and trumpet be,
To whose sound chaste wings obey.

But thou shrieking harbinger,
Foul precurrer of the fiend,
Augur of the fever's end,
To this troop come thou not near.

From this session interdict
Every fowl of tyrant wing,
Save the eagle, feather'd king;
Keep the obsequy so strict.

Let the priest in surplice white,
That defunctive music can,
Be the death-divining swan,
Lest the requiem lack his right.

And thou treble-dated crow,
That thy sable gender mak'st
With the breath thou giv'st and tak'st,
'Mongst our mourners shalt thou go.

Here the anthem doth commence:
Love and constancy is dead;
Phoenix and the Turtle fled
In a mutual flame from hence.

So they lov'd, as love in twain
Had the essence but in one;
Two distincts, division none:
Number there in love was slain.

Hearts remote, yet not asunder;
Distance and no space was seen
'Twixt this Turtle and his queen:
But in them it were a wonder.

So between them love did shine
That the Turtle saw his right
Flaming in the Phoenix' sight:
Either was the other's mine.

Property was thus appalled
That the self was not the same;
Single nature's double name
Neither two nor one was called.

Reason, in itself confounded,
Saw division grow together,
To themselves yet either neither,
Simple were so well compounded;

That it cried, "How true a twain
Seemeth this concordant one!
Love has reason, reason none,
If what parts can so remain."

Whereupon it made this threne
To the Phoenix and the Dove,
Co-supremes and stars of love,
As chorus to their tragic scene:

                 threnos

Beauty, truth, and rarity,
Grace in all simplicity,
Here enclos'd, in cinders lie.

Death is now the Phoenix' nest,
And the Turtle's loyal breast
To eternity doth rest,

Leaving no posterity:
'Twas not their infirmity,
It was married chastity.

Truth may seem but cannot be;
Beauty brag but 'tis not she;
Truth and beauty buried be.

To this urn let those repair
That are either true or fair;
For these dead birds sigh a prayer.
con: let bird loudest lay sole arabian tree herald sad trumpet whose sound chaste wing obey thou shrieking harbinger foul recurred fiend augury fever end troop come thou near session intersect every fowl tyrant wing save eagle feather king keep obsequy strict let priest surpliced white defective music deathdivining swan lest required lack right thou trebledated crow thy sable gender mast breath thou gist take amongst corner shalt thou go doth commence love constancy dead phoenix turtle fled mutual flame hence love love twain essence one two distinct division none number love slain heart remote yet asunder distance space seen twist turtle queen wonder love shine turtle saw right flaming phoenix sight either others mine property thus appalled self single nature double name neither two one called reason confounded saw division grow together yet either neither simple well compound cried true twain seemed concordant one love reason reason none part remain whereupon made three phoenix dove cosupremes star love chorus tragic scene thread beauty truth rarity grace simplicity enclosed hinders lie death phoenix nest turtle loyal breast eternity doth rest leaving posterity twas infirmity married hastily truth may seem cannot beauty brag ti truth beauty buried turn let repair either true fair dead bird sigh prayer

author: GEORGE GASCOIGNE
content: sing lullaby women therewith bring babes rest lullaby sing womanly best lullaby still child much beguiled full many wanton babes must skilled lullaby first lullaby youthful years time go bed crooked age hoar hairs within head lullaby youth still lullaby content thy since courage nails comes behind go sleep guile thy mind next lullaby gazing eyes wonted glance apace every glass may suffice show furrows face lullaby wink awhile lullaby looks guile let fair face beauty bright entice left vain delight lullaby wanton let reasons rule reign thy thought since late find skill dear thy fancies bought lullaby take thine ease lullaby thy doubts appease trust thou still body shall obey thy eye lullaby loving boy little robin take thy rest since age cold nothing boy keep close thy coin best lullaby thou content lullaby thy lasts relent let others pay hath mo pence thou art poor expense thus lullaby youth mine eyes ware mo delays devise welcome pain let pleasure pass lullaby take leave lullaby dreams deceive rise waking eye remember lullaby
ori_content:
Sing lullaby, as women do,
Wherewith they bring their babes to rest,
And lullaby can I sing too
As womanly as can the best.
With lullaby they still the child,
And if I be not much beguiled,
Full many wanton babes have I
Which must be stilled with lullaby.

     First lullaby my youthful years;
It is now time to go to bed,
For crooked age and hoary hairs
Have won the haven within my head.
With lullaby, then, youth be still;
With lullaby content thy will;
Since courage quails and comes behind,
Go sleep, and so beguile thy mind.

     Next, lullaby my gazing eyes,
Which wonted were to glance apace.
For every glass may now suffice
To show the furrows in my face;
With lullaby then wink awhile,
With lullaby your looks beguile;
Let no fair face nor beauty bright
Entice you eft with vain delight.

     And lullaby, my wanton will;
Let reason's rule now reign thy thought,
Since all too late I find by skill
How dear I have thy fancies bought;
With lullaby now take thine ease,
With lullaby thy doubts appease.
For trust to this: if thou be still,
My body shall obey thy will.

     Eke lullaby, my loving boy,
My little Robin, take thy rest;
Since age is cold and nothing coy,
Keep close thy coin, for so is best;
With lullaby be thou content,
With lullaby thy lusts relent,
Let others pay which hath mo pence;
Thou art too poor for such expense.

     Thus lullaby, my youth, mine eyes,
My will, my ware, and all that was.
I can no mo delays devise,
But welcome pain, let pleasure pass;
With lullaby now take your leave,
With lullaby your dreams deceive;
And when you rise with waking eye,
Remember then this lullaby.
con: sing lullaby woman therewith bring babe rest lullaby sing womanly best lullaby still child much beguiled full many wanton babe must skilled lullaby first lullaby youthful year time go bed crooked age hoar hair within head lullaby youth still lullaby content thy since courage nail come behind go sleep guile thy mind next lullaby gazing eye wonted glance apace every glass may suffice show furrow face lullaby wink awhile lullaby look guile let fair face beauty bright entice left vain delight lullaby wanton let reason rule reign thy thought since late find skill dear thy fancy bought lullaby take thine ease lullaby thy doubt appease trust thou still body shall obey thy eye lullaby loving boy little robin take thy rest since age cold nothing boy keep close thy coin best lullaby thou content lullaby thy last relent let others pay hath mo penny thou art poor expense thus lullaby youth mine eye ware mo delay devise welcome pain let pleasure pas lullaby take leave lullaby dream deceive rise waking eye remember lullaby

author: WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE
content: beshrew heart makes heart groan deep wound gives friend ist enough torture alone slave slavery sweets friend must thy cruel eye hath taken next self thou harder hast engrossed thee forsaken torment thrice threefold thus crossed prison heart thy steel bosoms ward friends heart let poor heart bail whoever keeps let heart guard thou canst use rigor jail yet thou wilt pent thee performed thine
poem name: Sonnet 133: Beshrew that heart that makes my heart to groan
ori_content:
Beshrew that heart that makes my heart to groan
For that deep wound it gives my friend and me:
Ist not enough to torture me alone,
But slave to slavery my sweetst friend must be?
Me from myself thy cruel eye hath taken,
And my next self thou harder hast engrossed;
Of him, myself, and thee I am forsaken,
A torment thrice threefold thus to be crossed.
Prison my heart in thy steel bosom's ward,
But then my friend's heart let my poor heart bail;
Whoeer keeps me, let my heart be his guard:
Thou canst not then use rigour in my jail.
    And yet thou wilt; for I, being pent in thee,
    Perforce am thine, and all that is in me.
con: beshrew heart make heart groan deep wound give friend ist enough torture alone slave slavery sweet friend must thy cruel eye hath taken next self thou harder hast engrossed thee forsaken torment thrice threefold thus crossed prison heart thy steel bosom ward friend heart let poor heart bail whoever keep let heart guard thou canst use rigor jail yet thou wilt pent thee performed thine

author: WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE
content: call justify wrong thy kindness lays upon heart wound thine eye thy tongue use power power slay art tell thou lost elsewhere sight dear heart forbear glance thine eye aside needs thou wound cunning thy might expressed defense bide let excuse thee ah love well knows pretty looks mine enemies therefore face turns foes elsewhere might dart injuries yet since near slain kill outright looks rid pain
poem name: Sonnet 139: O, call not me to justify the wrong
ori_content:
O, call not me to justify the wrong
That thy unkindness lays upon my heart;
Wound me not with thine eye but with thy tongue;
Use power with power, and slay me not by art.
Tell me thou lovst elsewhere; but in my sight,
Dear heart, forbear to glance thine eye aside;
What needst thou wound with cunning when thy might
Is more than my oerpressed defense can bide?
Let me excuse thee: ah, my love well knows
Her pretty looks have been mine enemies;
And therefore from my face she turns my foes,
That they elsewhere might dart their injuries
    Yet do not so; but since I am near slain,
    Kill me outright with looks and rid my pain.
con: call justify wrong thy kindness lay upon heart wound thine eye thy tongue use power power slay art tell thou lost elsewhere sight dear heart forbear glance thine eye aside need thou wound cunning thy might expressed defense bide let excuse thee ah love well know pretty look mine enemy therefore face turn foe elsewhere might dart injury yet since near slain kill outright look rid pain

author: WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE
content: love sin thy dear virtue hate hate sin grounded sinful loving mine compare thou thine state thou shalt find merits reproving lips thine profane scarlet ornaments sealed false bonds love oft mine robbed others beds revenues rents lawful love thee thou lost thine eyes mine important thee root pity thy heart grows thy pity may deserve pitied thou dost seek thou dost hide selfexample mast thou denied
poem name: Sonnet 142: Love is my sin, and thy dear virtue hate
ori_content:
Love is my sin, and thy dear virtue hate,
Hate of my sin, grounded on sinful loving.
O, but with mine compare thou thine own state,
And thou shalt find it merits not reproving;
Or if it do, not from those lips of thine,
That have profaned their scarlet ornaments
And sealed false bonds of love as oft as mine,
Robbed others beds revenues of their rents.
Be it lawful I love thee as thou lovst those
Whom thine eyes woo as mine importune thee:
Root pity in thy heart, that, when it grows,
Thy pity may deserve to pitied be.
    If thou dost seek to have what thou dost hide,
    By self-example mayst thou be denied.
con: love sin thy dear virtue hate hate sin grounded sinful loving mine compare thou thine state thou shalt find merit reproving lip thine profane scarlet ornament sealed false bond love oft mine robbed others bed revenue rent lawful love thee thou lost thine eye mine important thee root pity thy heart grows thy pity may deserve pitied thou dost seek thou dost hide selfexample mast thou denied

author: WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE
content: love fever longing still longer nurse disease feeding doth preserve ill th uncertain sickly appetite please reason physician love angry prescriptions kept hath left desperate approve desire death physics except past cure reason past care franticmad evermore unrest thoughts discourse madmen random truth vainly expressed sworn thee fair thought thee bright art black hell dark night
poem name: Sonnet 147: My love is as a fever, longing still
ori_content:
My love is as a fever, longing still
For that which longer nurseth the disease,
Feeding on that which doth preserve the ill,
Th uncertain sickly appetite to please.
My reason, the physician to my love,
Angry that his prescriptions are not kept,
Hath left me, and I desperate now approve
Desire is death, which physic did except.
Past cure I am, now reason is past care,
And frantic-mad with evermore unrest;
My thoughts and my discourse as madmens are,
At random from the truth vainly expressed:
    For I have sworn thee fair, and thought thee bright,
    Who art as black as hell, as dark as night.
con: love fever longing still longer nurse disease feeding doth preserve ill th uncertain sickly appetite please reason physician love angry prescription kept hath left desperate approve desire death physic except past cure reason past care franticmad evermore unrest thought discourse madman random truth vainly expressed sworn thee fair thought thee bright art black hell dark night

author: DUCHESS OF NEWCASTLE MARGARET CAVENDISH
content: poet neither born bred witty poet married whose brain fresh pleasant spring fancies grow uses sing oft lean head listening hark catch words fancies mark garden show beauties take whereof post verse may make thus gardens gather flowers newly blown
ori_content:
A Poet am I neither born nor bred,
But to a witty poet married:
Whose brain is fresh and pleasant as the Spring,
Where Fancies grow and where the Muses sing.
There oft I lean my head, and listening, hark,
To catch his words and all his fancies mark:
And from that garden show of beauties take
Whereof a posy I in verse may make.
Thus I, that have no gardens of my own,
There gather flowers that are newly blown.
con: poet neither born bred witty poet married whose brain fresh pleasant spring fancy grow us sing oft lean head listening hark catch word fancy mark garden show beauty take whereof post verse may make thus garden gather flower newly blown

author: SIR PHILIP SIDNEY
content: loving truth fain verse love show dear might take pleasure pain pleasure might cause read reading might make know knowledge might pity win pity grace obtain sought fit words paint blackest face woe studying inventions fine wits entertain oft turning others leaves see thence would flow fresh fruitful shower upon sunburned brain words came halting forth wanting inventions stay invention natures child fled stepdame study blows others feet still seemed strangers way thus great child speak helpless throws biting trunk pen beating spite fool said muse look thy heart write
ori_content:
Loving in truth, and fain in verse my love to show,
That she, dear she, might take some pleasure of my pain,
Pleasure might cause her read, reading might make her know,
Knowledge might pity win, and pity grace obtain,
I sought fit words to paint the blackest face of woe,
Studying inventions fine, her wits to entertain,
Oft turning others leaves, to see if thence would flow
Some fresh and fruitful showers upon my sunburned brain.
But words came halting forth, wanting Inventions stay:
Invention, Natures child, fled step-dame Studys blows,
And others feet still seemed but strangers in my way.
Thus great with child to speak, and helpless in my throes,
Biting my truant pen, beating myself for spite:
Fool, said my Muse to me, look in thy heart and write.
con: loving truth fain verse love show dear might take pleasure pain pleasure might cause read reading might make know knowledge might pity win pity grace obtain sought fit word paint blackest face woe studying invention fine wit entertain oft turning others leaf see thence would flow fresh fruitful shower upon sunburned brain word came halting forth wanting invention stay invention nature child fled stepdame study blow others foot still seemed stranger way thus great child speak helpless throw biting trunk pen beating spite fool said muse look thy heart write

author: THOMAS BASTARD
content: miss hardly could agree striving superiority text says man wife one chief argument stood upon held one woman become held man one contended daily strife could ended till one wife
ori_content:
Misus and Mopsa hardly could agree,
Striving about superiority.
The text which says that man and wife are one,
Was the chief argument they stood upon. 
She held they both one woman should become,
He held both should be man, and both but one.
     So they contended daily, but the strife
     Could not be ended, till both were one wife.
con: miss hardly could agree striving superiority text say man wife one chief argument stood upon held one woman become held man one contended daily strife could ended till one wife

author: EDMUND SPENSER
content: joy life full oft loving bless lot lucky placed misha rue much mean love based equal heavens much grace rest ye might invent heavenly wit whose verse could encased glorious name golden monument since ye deign goodly relent thrill little worth little shall spent setting immortal praises forth whose lofty argument uplifting shall lift unto high degree
poem name: ['Joy of my life, full oft for loving you']
ori_content:
Joy of my life, full oft for loving you
    I bless my lot, that was so lucky placed:
    But then the more your own mishap I rue,
    That are so much by so mean love embased.
For had the equal heavens so much you graced
    In this as in the rest, ye might invent
    Some heavenly wit, whose verse could have enchased
    Your glorious name in golden monument.
But since ye deignd so goodly to relent
    To me your thrall, in whom is little worth,
    That little that I am shall all be spent
    In setting your immortal praises forth;
Whose lofty argument uplifting me
    Shall lift you up unto an high degree.
con: joy life full oft loving bless lot lucky placed misha rue much mean love based equal heaven much grace rest ye might invent heavenly wit whose verse could encased glorious name golden monument since ye deign goodly relent thrill little worth little shall spent setting immortal praise forth whose lofty argument uplifting shall lift unto high degree

author: LADY MARY WROTH
content: sweet shades doe seek give delight deemed delight vile place butt torment sorrow mine one disgrace taste joy vain pleasing sight show pleasures saw never night grief joints fanning smiling face appears day grief found never space yet sigh gone envied spite butt world woes doe ly else harms strive rely attend like servants bound heat desire frosts care prove wanting love yet surest doe love burned yet freeze better hell bee
ori_content:
Sweet shades why doe you seeke to give delight
    To mee who deeme delight in this vilde place
    Butt torment, sorrow, and mine owne disgrace
    To taste of joy, or your vaine pleasing sight;

Show them your pleasures who saw never night
    Of greife, wher joyings fauning, smiling face
    Appeers as day, wher griefe found never space
    Yett for a sigh, a grone, or envies spite;

Butt O on mee a world of woes doe ly,
    Or els on mee all harmes strive to rely,
    And to attend like servants bound to mee,

Heat in desire, while frosts of care I prove,
    Wanting my love, yett surfett doe with love
    Burne, and yett freeze, better in hell to bee.
con: sweet shade doe seek give delight deemed delight vile place butt torment sorrow mine one disgrace taste joy vain pleasing sight show pleasure saw never night grief joint fanning smiling face appears day grief found never space yet sigh gone envied spite butt world woe doe ly else harm strive rely attend like servant bound heat desire frost care prove wanting love yet surest doe love burned yet freeze better hell bee

author: LADY MARY WROTH
content: come darkness night becoming sorrow best light leave thy light fit lightsome soul darkness doth truly sure rest absence power doth mirth control trees hanging heads console sweet sommes parting leaves distress dying couler make griefefull role much alas sorrow rest thus dead leaves farewell carpets made fall branches mourning prove leaves naked bodies whose made hopeful greene either love trees leaves absence corners bee servile grieve like want see
ori_content:
Come darkest night, becoming sorrow best;
    Light; leave thy light; fitt for a lightsome soule;
    Darknes doth truly sure with mee oprest
    Whom absence power doth from mirthe controle:

The very trees with hanging heads condole
    Sweet sommers parting, and of leaves distrest
    In dying coulers make a griefe-full role;
    Soe much (alas) to sorrow are they prest,

Thus of dead leaves her farewell carpetts made:
    Theyr fall, theyr branches, all theyr mournings prove;
    With leavles, naked bodies, whose huese vade
    From hopefull greene, to wither in theyr love,

If trees, and leaves for absence, mourners bee
Noe mervaile that I grieve, who like want see.
con: come darkness night becoming sorrow best light leave thy light fit lightsome soul darkness doth truly sure rest absence power doth mirth control tree hanging head console sweet somme parting leaf distress dying couler make griefefull role much ala sorrow rest thus dead leaf farewell carpet made fall branch mourning prove leaf naked body whose made hopeful greene either love tree leaf absence corner bee servile grieve like want see

author: LADY MARY WROTH
content: love like bugler comes play rise minds draw wonders admire see cunningly wanting eyes yet deserve best sight desire wanton child fine fire pretty none sees disguise finely doe tricks wee fools hire badge office tirannies end pulling doth make parts stead eyes doth take men slight abuse sight nimble delightful skill butt play gained lost yet childlike wee sports refuse
ori_content:
Love like a jugler, comes to play his prise,
    And all minds draw his wonders to admire,
    To see how cuningly hee, wanting eyes,
    Can yett deseave the best sight of desire:

 The wanton child, how hee can faine his fire
    So pretely, as none sees his disguise!
    How finely doe his tricks, while wee fooles hire
    The badge, and office of his tirannies,

For in the end, such jugling hee doth make
    As hee our harts, in stead of eyes doth take
    For men can only by theyr slieghts abuse

The sight with nimble, and delightful skill;
    Butt if hee play, his gaine is our lost will:
    Yett childlike, wee can nott his sports refuse.
con: love like bugler come play rise mind draw wonder admire see cunningly wanting eye yet deserve best sight desire wanton child fine fire pretty none see disguise finely doe trick wee fool hire badge office tirannies end pulling doth make part stead eye doth take men slight abuse sight nimble delightful skill butt play gained lost yet childlike wee sport refuse

author: LADY MARY WROTH
content: time cause unrest hope bee blest cruel art thou turned first gavest life unto love still pleasure move change though ever burned thee slack left undue one loving rite thy rage bitter changing minutes shall see wherein may least happy bee thy favors estranging blame thy self folly time gave time butt bee holly true love ends best love unworthy love doth seek ends worthy love butt worth pretends thoughts prove stay thy swiftness cruel time left blessed crime joy may praise thee left pleasure sweetly wasting joy love faith wasting faces wings ill rays thee never shall thy glory dying bee thine one untying time longer live tis gained time lend since thy fame shall never end butt joy give
ori_content:
Time only cause of my unrest
By whom I hopd once to bee blest
    How cruell art thou turned?
That first gavst lyfe unto my love,
And still a pleasure nott to move
    Or change though ever burned;

Have I thee slackd, or left undun
One loving rite, and soe have wunn
    Thy rage or bitter changing?
That now noe minutes I shall see,
Wherein I may least happy bee
    Thy favors soe estranging.

Blame thy self, and nott my folly,
Time gave time butt to bee holly;
    True love such ends best loveth
Unworhty love doth seeke for ends
A worthy love butt worth pretends
    Nor other thoughts itt proveth:

Then stay thy swiftnes cruell time,
And lett mee once more blessed clime
    To joy, that I may prayse thee:
Lett mee pleasure sweetly tasting
Joy in love, and faith nott wasting
    And on fames wings Ile rayse thee:

Never shall thy glory dying
Bee untill thine owne untying
    That time noe longer liveth;
Tis a gaine such tyme to lend:
Since soe thy fame shall never end
    Butt joy for what she giveth.
con: time cause unrest hope bee blest cruel art thou turned first gavest life unto love still pleasure move change though ever burned thee slack left undue one loving rite thy rage bitter changing minute shall see wherein may least happy bee thy favor estranging blame thy self folly time gave time butt bee holly true love end best love unworthy love doth seek end worthy love butt worth pretend thought prove stay thy swiftness cruel time left blessed crime joy may praise thee left pleasure sweetly wasting joy love faith wasting face wing ill ray thee never shall thy glory dying bee thine one untying time longer live ti gained time lend since thy fame shall never end butt joy give

author: LADY MARY WROTH
content: love refuse seek find corner mind twice woven shine web ill made foul frame bastard father name cannot bee dear behold shall see faith hive love bee doe bring gained sting pray desert sinews vines hold loves life gained lying bare despair thus anotamise body heart rise true close trunk emblem chest power still shall rest joy entombe loves doom
poem name: from The Countesse of Montgomerys Urania: Love peruse me, seeke, and finde
ori_content:
Love peruse me, seeke, and finde
How each corner of my minde
            Is a twine
            Woven to shine.
Not a Webb ill made, foule framd,
Bastard not by Father namd,
            Such in me
            Cannot bee.
Deare behold me, you shall see
Faith the Hive, and love the Bee,
            Which doe bring.
            Gaine and sting.
Pray desect me, sinewes, vaines,
Hold, and loves life in those gaines;
            Lying bare
            To despaire,
When you thus anotamise
All my body, my heart prise;
            Being true
            Just to you.
Close the Truncke, embalme the Chest,
Where your power still shall rest,
            Joy entombe,
            Loves just doome.
con: love refuse seek find corner mind twice woven shine web ill made foul frame bastard father name cannot bee dear behold shall see faith hive love bee doe bring gained sting pray desert sinew vine hold love life gained lying bare despair thus anotamise body heart rise true close trunk emblem chest power still shall rest joy entombe love doom

author: LADY MARY WROTH
content: beheld image deer greedy looked mine eyes would way bend fear desire inwardly contend fear bee marked desire drawn still soul spirit would peer boldness warranted pretend bee genius yet durst lend eyes trust others seemed clear search whence danger rose unworthiness rest stern eyes must sight bee blest jealousies poison disclose yet hart unseen jealous eye truer image shall triumph eye
ori_content:
When I beeheld the Image of my deere
    With greedy lookes mine eyes would that way bend,
    Fear, and desire did inwardly contend;
    Feare to bee markd, desire to drawe still neere,

And in my soule a speritt wowld apeer,
    Which boldnes waranted, and did pretend
    To bee my genius, yett I durst nott lend
    My eyes in trust wher others seemed soe cleere,

Then did I search from whence this danger rose,
    If such unworthynes in mee did rest
    As my stervd eyes must nott with sight bee blest;
    When jealousie her poyson did disclose;

Yett in my hart unseense of jealous eye
The truer Image shall in triumph lye.
con: beheld image deer greedy looked mine eye would way bend fear desire inwardly contend fear bee marked desire drawn still soul spirit would peer boldness warranted pretend bee genius yet durst lend eye trust others seemed clear search whence danger rose unworthiness rest stern eye must sight bee blest jealousy poison disclose yet hart unseen jealous eye truer image shall triumph eye

author: RICHARD BARNFIELD
content: long long see love still wish never could obtained rather world might gained would desire loves sweet precious gained yet soul see reverie day see see still sterne countenance ah long continuance majestic beauties bears sway sometimes imagine see love full foolish fantasies weeping kissed lips loves fees feel nothing bee thus union kissed clouds vain thus union feel endless paine
ori_content:
Long have I longd to see my love againe,
Still have I wisht, but never could obtaine it;
Rather than all the world (if I might gaine it)
Would I desire my loves sweet precious gaine.
Yet in my soule I see him everie day,
See him, and see his still sterne countenaunce,
But (ah) what is of long continuance,
Where majestie and beautie beares the sway?
Sometimes, when I imagine that I see him,
(As love is full of foolish fantasies)
Weening to kisse his lips, as my loves fees,
I feele but aire: nothing but aire to bee him.
Thus with Ixion, kisse I clouds in vaine:
Thus with Ixion, feele I endles paine.
con: long long see love still wish never could obtained rather world might gained would desire love sweet precious gained yet soul see reverie day see see still sterne countenance ah long continuance majestic beauty bear sway sometimes imagine see love full foolish fantasy weeping kissed lip love fee feel nothing bee thus union kissed cloud vain thus union feel endless paine

author: RICHARD BARNFIELD
content: cherrylipt agonies snow shape might compare pure ivory white whose faire front poets pen may write whose prostate red excess crimson grape loveenticing delicate soft limbs rarely frame intra poor gazing eyes cheeks willie caseation dies lovely tincture apollon dim lips ripe strawberries near wet mouth hive tongue honycombe uses like bees make mansion teeth pure pearls blushing cornell set oh body sinneprocuring slow love quick hate enduring
ori_content:
Cherry-lipt Adonis in his snowie shape,
    Might not compare with his pure ivorie white,
    On whose faire front a poets pen may write,
Whose roseate red excels the crimson grape,
His love-enticing delicate soft limbs,
    Are rarely framd tintrap poore gazine eies:
    His cheeks, the lillie and carnation dies,
With lovely tincture which Apollos dims.
His lips ripe strawberries in nectar wet,
    His mouth a Hive, his tongue a hony-combe,
    Where Muses (like bees) make their mansion.
His teeth pure pearle in blushing correll set.
    Oh how can such a body sinne-procuring,
    Be slow to love, and quicke to hate, enduring?
con: cherrylipt agony snow shape might compare pure ivory white whose faire front poet pen may write whose prostate red excess crimson grape loveenticing delicate soft limb rarely frame intra poor gazing eye cheek willie caseation dy lovely tincture apollon dim lip ripe strawberry near wet mouth hive tongue honycombe us like bee make mansion teeth pure pearl blushing cornell set oh body sinneprocuring slow love quick hate enduring

author: SIR THOMAS WYATT
content: flee sometime seek naked foot talking chamber seen gentle tame meek wild remember sometime put danger take bread hand range busily seeking continual change thanked fortune hath otherwise twenty times better special thin array pleasant guise loose gown shoulders fall caught arms long small therewith sweetly kiss softly said dear heart like dream lay broad waking turned thorough gentleness strange fashion forsaking leave go goodness also use newfangleness since kindly served would fain know hath deserved
ori_content:
They flee from me, that sometime did me seek
    With naked foot, stalking in my chamber.
I have seen them gentle, tame, and meek,
    That now are wild, and do not remember
    That sometime they put themselves in danger
         To take bread at my hand; and now they range
         Busily seeking with a continual change.

Thanked be fortune it hath been otherwise
    Twenty times better; but once, in special,
In thin array, after a pleasant guise,
    When her loose gown from her shoulders did fall,
    And she me caught in her arms long and small;
         Therewith all sweetly did me kiss,
         And softly said, Dear heart, how like you this?

It was no dream: I lay broad waking:
    But all is turned, thorough my gentleness,
Into a strange fashion of forsaking;
    And I have leave to go of her goodness,
    And she also to use newfangleness.
         But since that I so kindly am served,
         I would fain know what she hath deserved.
con: flee sometime seek naked foot talking chamber seen gentle tame meek wild remember sometime put danger take bread hand range busily seeking continual change thanked fortune hath otherwise twenty time better special thin array pleasant guise loose gown shoulder fall caught arm long small therewith sweetly kiss softly said dear heart like dream lay broad waking turned thorough gentleness strange fashion forsaking leave go goodness also use newfangleness since kindly served would fain know hath deserved

author: JOHN DONNE
content: tis true tis day though wilt thou therefore rise rise tis light lie twas night love spite darkness brought us hither despite light keep us together light hath tongue eye could speak well spy worst could say well fain would stay loved heart honour would go must business thee hence remove oh worst disease love poor foul false love admit busied man hath business makes love doth wrong married man doth
ori_content:
Tis true, tis day, what though it be?
O wilt thou therefore rise from me?
Why should we rise because tis light?
Did we lie down because twas night?
Love, which in spite of darkness brought us hither,
Should in despite of light keep us together.

Light hath no tongue, but is all eye;
If it could speak as well as spy,
This were the worst that it could say,
That being well I fain would stay,
And that I loved my heart and honour so,
That I would not from him, that had them, go.

Must business thee from hence remove?
Oh, thats the worst disease of love,
The poor, the foul, the false, love can
Admit, but not the busied man.
He which hath business, and makes love, doth do
Such wrong, as when a married man doth woo.
con: ti true ti day though wilt thou therefore rise rise ti light lie twas night love spite darkness brought u hither despite light keep u together light hath tongue eye could speak well spy worst could say well fain would stay loved heart honour would go must business thee hence remove oh worst disease love poor foul false love admit busied man hath business make love doth wrong married man doth

author: SECOND BARON VAUX OF HARROWDEN THOMAS, LORD VAUX
content: loathe love youth thought sweet time requires behave methinks meet lasts leave fancies fled tract time begins weave grey hairs upon head age stealing steps hath called crutch lusty life away leaps none muse doth delight hand pen plight yore reason denied youth idle rhyme day day cries leave toys time wrinkles brow furrows face say limping age lodge youth must give place harbingers death see ride cough cold gasping breath doth bid provide package spade eye shouting sheet house clay made guest meet methinks hear clark knoll careful knell bids leave useful war ere nature compel keepers knit knot youth laugh scorn clean shall forgot born thus must youth give whose badge long wear yield wanton cup better may bear lo bared skull whose bald sign know stooping age away shall pull youthful years sow beauty band crooked cares hath wrought shipped land whence first brought ye bide behind ye none trust ye clay cast kind shall ye waste dust
ori_content:
I loathe that I did love,
In youth that I thought sweet,
As time requires for my behove,
Methinks they are not meet.

My lusts they do me leave,
My fancies all be fled,
And tract of time begins to weave
Grey hairs upon my head,

For age with stealing steps
Hath clawed me with his crutch,
And lusty life away she leaps
As there had been none such.

My Muse doth not delight
Me as she did before;
My hand and pen are not in plight,
As they have been of yore.

For reason me denies
This youthly idle rhyme;
And day by day to me she cries,
Leave off these toys in time.

The wrinkles in my brow,
The furrows in my face,
Say, limping age will lodge him now
Where youth must give him place.

The harbinger of death,
To me I see him ride,
The cough, the cold, the gasping breath
Doth bid me provide

A pickaxe and a spade,
And eke a shrouding sheet,
A house of clay for to be made
For such a guest most meet.

Methinks I hear the clark
That knolls the careful knell,
And bids me leave my woeful wark,
Ere nature me compel.

My keepers knit the knot
That youth did laugh to scorn,
Of me that clean shall be forgot
As I had not been born.

Thus must I youth give up,
Whose badge I long did wear;
To them I yield the wanton cup
That better may it bear.

Lo, here the bared skull,
By whose bald sign I know
That stooping age away shall pull
Which youthful years did sow.

For beauty with her band
These crooked cares hath wrought,
And shipped me into the land
From whence I first was brought.

And ye that bide behind,
Have ye none other trust:
As ye of clay were cast by kind,
So shall ye waste to dust.
con: loathe love youth thought sweet time requires behave methinks meet last leave fancy fled tract time begin weave grey hair upon head age stealing step hath called crutch lusty life away leap none muse doth delight hand pen plight yore reason denied youth idle rhyme day day cry leave toy time wrinkle brow furrow face say limping age lodge youth must give place harbinger death see ride cough cold gasping breath doth bid provide package spade eye shouting sheet house clay made guest meet methinks hear clark knoll careful knell bid leave useful war ere nature compel keeper knit knot youth laugh scorn clean shall forgot born thus must youth give whose badge long wear yield wanton cup better may bear lo bared skull whose bald sign know stooping age away shall pull youthful year sow beauty band crooked care hath wrought shipped land whence first brought ye bide behind ye none trust ye clay cast kind shall ye waste dust

author: HENRY HOWARD, EARL OF SURREY
content: alas things hold peace heaven earth disturbed thing beasts air birds song cease nights car stars doth bring calm sea waves work less less love alas doth wring bringing face great increase desires whereas weep sing joy woe doubtful case sweet thoughts sometime pleasure bring cause disease gives pang inwardly doth sting think grief live lack thing rid pain
poem name: "Alas, so all things now do hold their peace!"
ori_content:
Alas, so all things now do hold their peace!
   Heaven and earth disturbed in no thing;
The beasts, the air, the birds their song do cease,
   The nightes car the stars about doth bring;
Calm is the sea; the waves work less and less:
   So am not I, whom love, alas! doth wring,
Bringing before my face the great increase
   Of my desires, whereat I weep and sing,
In joy and woe, as in a doubtful case.
   For my sweet thoughts sometime do pleasure bring:
But by and by, the cause of my disease
   Gives me a pang that inwardly doth sting,
When that I think what grief it is again
To live and lack the thing should rid my pain.
con: ala thing hold peace heaven earth disturbed thing beast air bird song cease night car star doth bring calm sea wave work le le love ala doth wring bringing face great increase desire whereas weep sing joy woe doubtful case sweet thought sometime pleasure bring cause disease give pang inwardly doth sting think grief live lack thing rid pain

author: EDMUND SPENSER
content: happy ye leaves silly hands hold life dead might shall handle hold loves soft bands like captives trembling victors sight happy lines starry light limping eyes deign sometimes look ready sorrows dying upright written tears parts close bleeding book happy rimes bath sacred broke helicon whence derived ye behold angels blessed looked souls long lacked food heavens bliss leaves lines rimes seek please alone ye please care none
poem name: Amoretti I: Happy ye leaves when as those lilly hands
ori_content:
Happy ye leaves when as those lilly hands,
Which hold my life in their dead doing might
Shall handle you and hold in loves soft bands,
Lyke captives trembling at the victors sight.
And happy lines, on which with starry light,
Those lamping eyes will deigne sometimes to look
And reade the sorrowes of my dying spright,
Written with teares in harts close bleeding book.
And happy rymes bathd in the sacred brooke,
Of Helicon whence she derived is,
When ye behold that Angels blessed looke,
My soules long lacked foode, my heavens blis.
Leaves, lines, and rymes, seeke her to please alone,
Whom if ye please, I care for other none.
con: happy ye leaf silly hand hold life dead might shall handle hold love soft band like captive trembling victor sight happy line starry light limping eye deign sometimes look ready sorrow dying upright written tear part close bleeding book happy rime bath sacred broke helicon whence derived ye behold angel blessed looked soul long lacked food heaven bliss leaf line rime seek please alone ye please care none

author: EDMUND SPENSER
content: new years forth looking anus gate doth seemed promise hope new delight bidding told adieu pass
poem name: Amoretti IV: "New yeare forth looking out of Janus gate"
ori_content:
New yeare forth looking out of Janus gate,
Doth seeme to promise hope of new delight:
And bidding thold Adieu, his pass
con: new year forth looking anus gate doth seemed promise hope new delight bidding told adieu pas

author: EDMUND SPENSER
content: worlds theatre stay love like spectator idly sits holding agents play disguising diverse troubled wits sometimes joy glad occasion fits mask mirth like comedy soon joy sorrow fits make woes tragedy yet holding constant eye delights mirth rules smart laugh locks cry laughed gardens evermore hart move mirth one woman senseless stone
poem name: Amoretti LIV: Of this worlds Theatre in which we stay
ori_content:
Of this worlds Theatre in which we stay,
My love lyke the Spectator ydly sits
Beholding me that all the pageants play,
Disguysing diversly my troubled wits.
Sometimes I joy when glad occasion fits,
And mask in myrth lyke to a Comedy:
Soone after when my joy to sorrow flits,
I waile and make my woes a Tragedy.
Yet she beholding me with constant eye,
Delights not in my merth nor rues my smart:
But when I laugh she mocks, and when I cry
She laughes, and hardens evermore her hart.
What then can move her? if not merth nor mone,
She is no woman, but a sencelesse stone.
con: world theatre stay love like spectator idly sits holding agent play disguising diverse troubled wit sometimes joy glad occasion fit mask mirth like comedy soon joy sorrow fit make woe tragedy yet holding constant eye delight mirth rule smart laugh lock cry laughed garden evermore hart move mirth one woman senseless stone

author: EDMUND SPENSER
content: oft beauty behold therewith cruelty compare marvel substance mould made cruelfair earth high thoughts heavenly water love doth burn like fire air light rare fire doth freeze faint desire needs another element inquire whereof might made sky heaven haughty looks spire eye love pure immortal high since heaven ye likened best like mercy rest
poem name: Amoretti LV: So oft as I her beauty do behold
ori_content:
So oft as I her beauty do behold,
And therewith do her cruelty compare,
I marvel of what substance was the mould
The which her made at once so cruel-fair.
Not earth; for her high thoughts more heavenly are:
Not water; for her love doth burn like fire:
Not air; for she is not so light or rare:
Not fire; for she doth freeze with faint desire.

Then needs another element inquire
Whereof she might be made; that is, the sky.
For to the heaven her haughty looks aspire,
And eke her love is pure immortal high.
Then since to heaven ye likened are the best,
Be like in mercy as in all the rest.
con: oft beauty behold therewith cruelty compare marvel substance mould made cruelfair earth high thought heavenly water love doth burn like fire air light rare fire doth freeze faint desire need another element inquire whereof might made sky heaven haughty look spire eye love pure immortal high since heaven ye likened best like mercy rest

author: EDMUND SPENSER
content: weary years race run new begins compact course anew shew morning made hath begun betokening peace plenty new let us change weather new change minds former lives amend old years sinners forecast let us screw fly faults offend shall new years joy forth freshly send looming world gladsome ray stories beauty blend shall turned causes timely clear away likewise love chere heavy upright change old years annoy new delight
poem name: Amoretti LXII: "The weary yeare his race now having run"
ori_content:
The weary yeare his race now having run,
The new begins his compast course anew:
With shew of morning mylde he hath begun,
Betokening peace and plenty to ensew.
So let us, which this chaunge of weather vew,
Chaunge eeke our mynds and former lives amend,
The old yeares sinnes forepast let us eschew,
And fly the faults with which we did offend.
Then shall the new yeares joy forth freshly send,
Into the glooming world his gladsome ray:
And all these stormes which now his beauty blend,
Shall turne to caulmes and tymely cleare away.
So likewise love cheare you your heavy spright,
And chaunge old yeares annoy to new delight.
con: weary year race run new begin compact course anew shew morning made hath begun betokening peace plenty new let u change weather new change mind former life amend old year sinner forecast let u screw fly fault offend shall new year joy forth freshly send looming world gladsome ray story beauty blend shall turned cause timely clear away likewise love chere heavy upright change old year annoy new delight

author: EDMUND SPENSER
content: happy blessings ye plenteous hand heaven upon thrown one disparagement gave ye love lent means one see whose high worth surpassing pardon could earth found one fit mate ne heaven matchable none ye stop unto lowly state ye thereby much greater glory gate ye sorted princes pere light doth self dilate darkness greater doth appeared yet since light hath enlumind reflex shall increased
poem name: Amoretti LXVI: "To all those happy blessings which ye have"
ori_content:
To all those happy blessings which ye have,
With plenteous hand by heaven upon you thrown:
This one disparagement they to you gave,
That ye your love lent to so meane a one.
Yee whose high worths surpassing paragon,
Could not on earth have found one fit for mate,
Ne but in heaven matchable to none,
Why did ye stoup unto so lowly state.
But ye thereby much greater glory gate,
Then had ye sorted with a princes pere:
For now your light doth more it selfe dilate,
And in my darknesse greater doth appeare.
Yet since your light hath once enlumind me,
With my reflex yours shall encreased be.
con: happy blessing ye plenteous hand heaven upon thrown one disparagement gave ye love lent mean one see whose high worth surpassing pardon could earth found one fit mate ne heaven matchable none ye stop unto lowly state ye thereby much greater glory gate ye sorted prince pere light doth self dilate darkness greater doth appeared yet since light hath enlumind reflex shall increased

author: EDMUND SPENSER
content: fresh spring herald loves mighty king whose come armour richly displayed sorts flowers earth spring goodly colours glorious array go love careless lay yet winters bore well awake tell joyous time staid unless doe forelock take bid therefore self soon ready make way love amongst lovely crew every one missed make shall hearst penance dew make hast therefore sweet love whilst prime none call passed time
poem name: Amoretti LXX: Fresh spring the herald of loves mighty king
ori_content:
Fresh spring the herald of loves mighty king,
In whose cote armour richly are displayed
All sorts of flowers the which on earth do spring
In goodly colours gloriously arrayd:
Goe to my love, where she is carelesse layd,
Yet in her winters bowre not well awake:
Tell her the joyous time wil not be staid
Unless she doe him by the forelock take.
Bid her therefore her selfe soone ready make,
To wayt on love amongst his lovely crew:
Where every one that misseth then her make,
Shall be by him amearst with penance dew.
Make hast therefore sweet love, whilest it is prime,
For none can call againe the passed time.
con: fresh spring herald love mighty king whose come armour richly displayed sort flower earth spring goodly colour glorious array go love careless lay yet winter bore well awake tell joyous time staid unless doe forelock take bid therefore self soon ready make way love amongst lovely crew every one missed make shall hearst penance dew make hast therefore sweet love whilst prime none call passed time

author: EDMUND SPENSER
content: joy see drawn work self unto bee ye doe compare unto spider doth burke close away catch unaware right self caught cunning snare dear thrilled love whose straight bands ye captive firmly ye never may remove whole work woven woodland flowers fragrant enlantine sweet prison time shall prove many dear delights decked fine thenceforth eternal peace shall see spider gentle bee
poem name: Amoretti LXXI: I joy to see how in your drawen work
ori_content:
I joy to see how in your drawen work,
Your selfe unto the Bee ye doe compare;
And me unto the Spyder that doth lurke,
In close awayt to catch her unaware.
Right so your selfe were caught in cunning snare
Of a deare for, and thralled to his love:
In whose streight bands ye now captived are
So firmely, that ye never may remove.
But as your whole worke is woven all about,
With woodbynd flowers and fragrant Enlantine:
So sweet your prison you in time shall prove,
With many deare delights bedecked fyne,
And all thensforth eternall peace shall see
Betweene the Spyder and the gentle Bee.
con: joy see drawn work self unto bee ye doe compare unto spider doth burke close away catch unaware right self caught cunning snare dear thrilled love whose straight band ye captive firmly ye never may remove whole work woven woodland flower fragrant enlantine sweet prison time shall prove many dear delight decked fine thenceforth eternal peace shall see spider gentle bee

author: EDMUND SPENSER
content: faire love faire golden hearts loose wind ye waving chance make faire rose red cheeks appears eyes fire love spare faire brest like rich laden bare previous merchandise forth doth lay faire cloud pride oft doth dark goodly light smiles drives away fairest doth display gate pearls rubles richly right words wise make way bear message gentle upright rest works natures wonderment work parts astonishment
poem name: Amoretti LXXXI: Fayre is my love, when her fayre golden heares
ori_content:
Fayre is my love, when her fayre golden heares,
With the loose wynd ye waving chance to marke:
Fayre when the rose in her red cheekes appears,
Or in her eyes the fyre of love does sparke.
Fayre when her brest lyke a rich laden barke,
With pretious merchandize she forth doth lay:
Fayre when that cloud of pryde which oft doth dark
Her goodly light with smiles she drives away,
But fayrest she, when so she doth display
The gate with pearles and rubyes richly dight:
Throgh which her words so wise do make their way
To beare the message of her gentle spright.
The rest be works of natures wonderment,
But this the worke of harts astonishment.
