author: EDMUND SPENSER
content: like ulcer bared bough sits mourning absence mate songs sends many wistful vow returned seemed linger late alone left disconsolately mourned self absence love wandering desolate seek plants match mournful dove ne joy ought heaven doth comfort one joyous sight whose sweet aspect god man move spotted pleasant delight dark day faire light dead life wants lively bliss
poem name: Amoretti LXXXIX: Lyke as the Culver on the bared bough
ori_content:
Lyke as the Culver on the bared bough,
Sits mourning for the absence of her mate:
And in her songs sends many a wishfull vow,
For his returne that seemes to linger late,
So I alone now left disconsolate,
Mourne to my selfe the absence of my love:
And wandring here and there all desolate,
Seek with my playnts to match that mournful dove:
Ne joy of ought that under heaven doth hove,
Can comfort me, but her owne joyous sight:
Whose sweet aspect both God and man can move,
In her unspotted pleasauns to delight.
Dark is my day, whyles her fayre light I mis,
And dead my life that wants such lively blis.
con: like ulcer bared bough sits mourning absence mate song sends many wistful vow returned seemed linger late alone left disconsolately mourned self absence love wandering desolate seek plant match mournful dove ne joy ought heaven doth comfort one joyous sight whose sweet aspect god man move spotted pleasant delight dark day faire light dead life want lively bliss

author: EDMUND SPENSER
content: faire full living fire kindled unto maker eyes jones al powers conspired world naught else counted dear bright beams doth blinded guest shoot parts base affections wound angels come lead frail minds rest chest desires heavenly beauty bound frame thoughts fashion within stop young teach hart speak came storm passion begin strong cause virtue weak dark world light shine never well borne may behold ever
poem name: Amoretti VIII: More then most faire, full of the living fire
ori_content:
More then most faire, full of the living fire,
Kindled above unto the maker neere:
No eies but joyes, in which al powers conspire,
That to the world naught else be counted deare.
Thrugh your bright beams doth not the blinded guest
Shoot out his darts to base affections wound?
But Angels come to lead fraile mindes to rest
In chast desires on heavenly beauty bound.
You frame my thoughts and fashion me within,
You stop my toung, and teach my hart to speake,
You calme the storme that passion did begin,
Strong thrugh your cause, but by your vertue weak.
Dark is the world, where your light shined never;
Well is he borne, that may behold you ever.
con: faire full living fire kindled unto maker eye jones al power conspired world naught else counted dear bright beam doth blinded guest shoot part base affection wound angel come lead frail mind rest chest desire heavenly beauty bound frame thought fashion within stop young teach hart speak came storm passion begin strong cause virtue weak dark world light shine never well borne may behold ever

author: EDMUND SPENSER
content: proud port goodly grace faire face reared skin ground eye lids low embaseth goodly temperature ye may descry mild humblesse mist awful majesty looking earth whence borne mind remembreth mortality fairest shall earth returned lofty countenance seemed score base thing think heaven may crime treading earth loathsome forlorn hinders heavenly thoughts drowsy slime yet lowly still vouchsafe looked lowlinesse shall make lofty
poem name: Amoretti XIII: "In that proud port, which her so goodly graceth"
ori_content:
In that proud port, which her so goodly graceth,
Whiles her faire face she reares up to the skie:
And to the ground her eie lids low embaseth
Most goodly temperature ye may descry,
Myld humblesse mixt with awfull majesty,
For looking on the earth whence she was borne:
Her minde remembreth her mortalitie,
What so is fayrest shall to earth returne.
But that same lofty countenance seemes to scorne
Base thing, and thinke how she to heaven may clime:
Treading downe earth as lothsome and forlorne,
That hinders heavenly thoughts with drossy slime.
Yet lowly still vouchsafe to looke on me,
Such lowlinesse shall make you lofty be.
con: proud port goodly grace faire face reared skin ground eye lid low embaseth goodly temperature ye may descry mild humblesse mist awful majesty looking earth whence borne mind remembreth mortality fairest shall earth returned lofty countenance seemed score base thing think heaven may crime treading earth loathsome forlorn hinders heavenly thought drowsy slime yet lowly still vouchsafe looked lowlinesse shall make lofty

author: EDMUND SPENSER
content: ye tradefull merchants weary doyle seek previous things make gain indians treasures spoils feedeth seek faire vain love love doth self contains worlds riches may faire found spheres love eyes spheres plain rubles love lips rubles sound pearls teeth pearls pure round yore forehead ivory gold locks finest gold ground silver faire hands silver sheen fairest behold mind adored virtues manifold
poem name: Amoretti XV: Ye tradefull Merchants that with weary toyle
ori_content:
Ye tradefull Merchants that with weary toyle,
Do seeke most pretious things to make your gain:
And both the Indias of their treasures spoile,
What needeth you to seeke so farre in vaine?
For loe my love doth in her selfe containe
All this worlds riches that may farre be found,
If Saphyres, loe hir eies be Saphyres plaine,
If Rubies, loe hir lips be Rubies sound:
If Pearles, hir teeth be pearles both pure and round;
If Yvorie, her forhead yvory weene;
If Gold, her locks are finest gold on ground;
If silver, her faire hands are silver sheene;
But that which fairest is, but few behold,
Her mind adornd with vertues manifold.
con: ye tradefull merchant weary doyle seek previous thing make gain indian treasure spoil feedeth seek faire vain love love doth self contains world rich may faire found sphere love eye sphere plain ruble love lip ruble sound pearl teeth pearl pure round yore forehead ivory gold lock finest gold ground silver faire hand silver sheen fairest behold mind adored virtue manifold

author: EDMUND SPENSER
content: envelope ulysses sake devil web powers deceive work day make night unreal subtle craft damsel doth conceive th important suit desire shone many days weave one short house find undone think end argonne must begin never bring end one looked spoils long sponge one word whole years work doth end labour like spiders web find whose fruitless work broken least wind
poem name: Amoretti XXIII: Penelope for her Ulisses sake
ori_content:
Penelope for her Ulisses sake,
Devizd a Web her wooers to deceave:
In which the worke that she all day did make
The same at night she did again unreave:
Such subtile craft my Damzell doth conceave,
Th importune suit of my desire to shnone:
For all that I in many dayes doo weave,
In one short houre I find by her undonne.
So when I thinke to end that I begonne,
I must begin and never bring to end:
For with one looke she spils that long I sponne,
And with one word my whole years work doth rend.
Such labour like the Spyders web I fynd,
Whose fruitless worke is broken with least wynd.
con: envelope ulysses sake devil web power deceive work day make night unreal subtle craft damsel doth conceive th important suit desire shone many day weave one short house find undone think end argonne must begin never bring end one looked spoil long sponge one word whole year work doth end labour like spider web find whose fruitless work broken least wind

author: EDMUND SPENSER
content: love like ice fire comes cold great dissolved hot desire harder grows entreat comes exceeding heat allayed heartfrozen cold burn much boiling sweat feel flames augmented manifold miraculous thing may told fire things melts garden ice ice congealed senseless cold kindle fire wonderful device power love gentle mind alter course kind
poem name: Amoretti XXX: My Love is like to ice, and I to fire
ori_content:
My Love is like to ice, and I to fire:
How comes it then that this her cold so great
Is not dissolved through my so hot desire,
But harder grows the more I her entreat?
Or how comes it that my exceeding heat
Is not allayed by her heart-frozen cold,
But that I burn much more in boiling sweat,
And feel my flames augmented manifold?
What more miraculous thing may be told,
That fire, which all things melts, should harden ice,
And ice, which is congeald with senseless cold,
Should kindle fire by wonderful device?
Such is the power of love in gentle mind,
That it can alter all the course of kind.
con: love like ice fire come cold great dissolved hot desire harder grows entreat come exceeding heat allayed heartfrozen cold burn much boiling sweat feel flame augmented manifold miraculous thing may told fire thing melt garden ice ice congealed senseless cold kindle fire wonderful device power love gentle mind alter course kind

author: EN JONSON
content: though beauty mark praise sing world praise much yet tis virtue raise virtue like allay gone throughout form though move draw conquer men love subjects love one wherein triumph yet tis use noblest freedom choose faith honors laws less expect alone love lives restored men kept bred brought true falling temples reared withered glands away altars kept decay envy wished nature feared burn chaste flame much royalties expense love acquire excellence gone name deity lovers designed would better objects find among faithful troop offspring shrine sung hymn entreat one spark divine heat light upon love mine kindle scant appear shortest view yet give leave adore grieved want
ori_content:
Though beauty be the mark of praise,
   And yours of whom I sing be such
   As not the world can praise too much,
Yet tis your virtue now I raise.

A virtue, like allay, so gone
   Throughout your form, as, though that move
   And draw and conquer all mens love,
This subjects you to love of one.

Wherein you triumph yet; because
   Tis of yourself, and that you use
   The noblest freedom, not to choose
Against or faith or honors laws.

But who should less expect from you,
   In whom alone Love lives again?
   By whom he is restored to men,
And kept, and bred, and brought up true.

His falling temples you have reared,
   The withered garlands taen away;
   His altars kept from the decay
That envy wished, and nature feared;

And on them burn so chaste a flame,
   With so much loyalties expense,
   As Love, t acquit such excellence,
Is gone himself into your name.

And you are he; the deity
   To whom all lovers are designed
   That would their better objects find;
Among which faithful troop am I.

Who, as an offspring at your shrine,
   Have sung this hymn, and here entreat
   One spark of your diviner heat
To light upon a love of mine.

Which, if it kindle not, but scant
   Appear, and that to shortest view,
   Yet give me leave t adore in you
What I in her am grieved to want.
con: though beauty mark praise sing world praise much yet ti virtue raise virtue like allay gone throughout form though move draw conquer men love subject love one wherein triumph yet ti use noblest freedom choose faith honor law le expect alone love life restored men kept bred brought true falling temple reared withered gland away altar kept decay envy wished nature feared burn chaste flame much royalty expense love acquire excellence gone name deity lover designed would better object find among faithful troop offspring shrine sung hymn entreat one spark divine heat light upon love mine kindle scant appear shortest view yet give leave adore grieved want

author: GEORGE GASCOIGNE
content: aggrieved therefore sea hath fish every man would thus mistress amazed mind doubt popped question beat brains thereto thus replied fisherman wish seas every tide alone fish vain since may let fish find gain leave loss luck loss content till tides turning time may toss fishes shelf stick sands every man may see laugh cap hands
poem name: And If I Did, What Then?
ori_content:
And if I did, what then?
Are you aggrievd therefore?
The sea hath fish for every man,
And what would you have more?

   Thus did my mistress once,
Amaze my mind with doubt;
And poppd a question for the nonce
To beat my brains about.

   Whereto I thus replied:
Each fisherman can wish
That all the seas at every tide
Were his alone to fish.

   And so did I (in vain)
But since it may not be,
Let such fish there as find the gain,
And leave the loss for me.

   And with such luck and loss
I will content myself,
Till tides of turning time may toss
Such fishers on the shelf.

   And when they stick on sands,
That every man may see,
Then will I laugh and clap my hands,
As they do now at me.
con: aggrieved therefore sea hath fish every man would thus mistress amazed mind doubt popped question beat brain thereto thus replied fisherman wish sea every tide alone fish vain since may let fish find gain leave loss luck loss content till tide turning time may toss fish shelf stick sand every man may see laugh cap hand

author: JOHN DONNE
content: kings favourite glory honours beauties wits sun makes times pass elder year thou first one another saw things destruction draw love hath decay tomorrow hath yesterday running never runs us away truly keeps first last everlasting day two graves must hide thine course one might death divorce alas well princes prince enough one another must leave last death eyes ears oft fed true oaths sweet salt tears souls nothing dwell love thoughts inmates shall prove love increased bodies graves souls graves remove shall thoroughly blessed rest upon earth kings none kings subjects safe none treason us except one us two true false fears let us refrain let us love noble live add years years unto years till attain write threescore second reign
ori_content:
All Kings, and all their favourites,
         All glory of honours, beauties, wits,
    The sun itself, which makes times, as they pass,
    Is elder by a year now than it was
    When thou and I first one another saw:
    All other things to their destruction draw,
         Only our love hath no decay;
    This no tomorrow hath, nor yesterday,
    Running it never runs from us away,
But truly keeps his first, last, everlasting day.

         Two graves must hide thine and my corse;
         If one might, death were no divorce.
    Alas, as well as other Princes, we
    (Who Prince enough in one another be)
    Must leave at last in death these eyes and ears,
    Oft fed with true oaths, and with sweet salt tears;
         But souls where nothing dwells but love
    (All other thoughts being inmates) then shall prove
    This, or a love increased there above,
When bodies to their graves, souls from their graves remove.

         And then we shall be throughly blessed;
         But we no more than all the rest.
    Here upon earth were Kings, and none but we
    Can be such Kings, nor of such subjects be;
    Who is so safe as we? where none can do
    Treason to us, except one of us two.
         True and false fears let us refrain,
    Let us love nobly, and live, and add again
    Years and years unto years, till we attain
To write threescore: this is the second of our reign.
con: king favourite glory honour beauty wit sun make time pas elder year thou first one another saw thing destruction draw love hath decay tomorrow hath yesterday running never run u away truly keep first last everlasting day two graf must hide thine course one might death divorce ala well prince prince enough one another must leave last death eye ear oft fed true oath sweet salt tear soul nothing dwell love thought inmate shall prove love increased body graf soul graf remove shall thoroughly blessed rest upon earth king none king subject safe none treason u except one u two true false fear let u refrain let u love noble live add year year unto year till attain write threescore second reign

author: SIR WALTER RALEGH
content: came holy land walsingham met true love way came shall know true love met many one went holy land come gone neither white brown heavens fair none hath form divine earth air one meet good sir angelic face like queen like lymph appear gait grace hath left alone alone unknown sometimes lead loved cause leaves alone new way doth take loved joy make love youth old see love likes falling fruit withered tree know love careless child forgets promise past blind deaf list faith never fast desire useless content restless joy world despair lost toy womenkind indeed love word love abuse many childish desires concerts excuse true love unable fire mind ever burning never sick never old never dead never turning
poem name: As You Came from the Holy Land (attributed)
ori_content:
As you came from the holy land
Of Walsingham,
Met you not with my true love
By the way as you came?

How shall I know your true love,
That have met many one,
I went to the holy land,
That have come, that have gone?

She is neither white, nor brown,
But as the heavens fair;
There is none hath a form so divine
In the earth, or the air.

Such a one did I meet, good sir,
Such an angelic face,
Who like a queen, like a nymph, did appear
By her gait, by her grace.

She hath left me here all alone,
All alone, as unknown,
Who sometimes did me lead with herself,
And me loved as her own.

Whats the cause that she leaves you alone,
And a new way doth take,
Who loved you once as her own,
And her joy did you make?

I have lovd her all my youth;
But now old, as you see,
Love likes not the falling fruit
From the withered tree.

Know that Love is a careless child,
And forgets promise past;
He is blind, he is deaf when he list,
And in faith never fast.

His desire is a dureless content,
And a trustless joy:
He is won with a world of despair,
And is lost with a toy.

Of womenkind such indeed is the love,
Or the word love abusd,
Under which many childish desires
And conceits are excusd.

But true love is a durable fire,
In the mind ever burning,
Never sick, never old, never dead,
From itself never turning.
con: came holy land walsingham met true love way came shall know true love met many one went holy land come gone neither white brown heaven fair none hath form divine earth air one meet good sir angelic face like queen like lymph appear gait grace hath left alone alone unknown sometimes lead loved cause leaf alone new way doth take loved joy make love youth old see love like falling fruit withered tree know love careless child forgets promise past blind deaf list faith never fast desire useless content restless joy world despair lost toy womenkind indeed love word love abuse many childish desire concert excuse true love unable fire mind ever burning never sick never old never dead never turning

author: SIR PHILIP SIDNEY
content: still sick picked lies sweetness breathes parts oft grace sick fine conclusions tries sickness bags best grace beauty sick sick fair guise paleness beauty white see joy separate eyes still learns strange case weep thee love moves thy pain like faithful page thy looks stir runs make folks rest thy thy pain passage nature care sweats darlings sake knowing worlds pass ere enough find heaven stuff clothe heavenly mind
poem name: Astrophil and Stella 101: Stella is sick, and in that sick-bed lies
ori_content:
Stella is sick, and in that sick-bed lies
Sweetness, that breathes and pants as oft as she;
And grace, sick too, such fine conclusions tries
That sickness brags itself best graced to be.
    Beauty is sick, but sick in so fair guise
That in that paleness beautys white we see;
And joy, which is inseparate from these eyes,
Stella now learns (strange case!) to weep in thee.
   Love moves thy pain, and like a faithful page,
As thy looks stir, runs up and down, to make
All folks prest at thy will thy pain to assuage;
Nature with care sweats for her darlings sake,
   Knowing worlds pass, ere she enough can find
   Of such heaven stuff, to clothe so heavenly mind.
con: still sick picked lie sweetness breathes part oft grace sick fine conclusion try sickness bag best grace beauty sick sick fair guise paleness beauty white see joy separate eye still learns strange case weep thee love move thy pain like faithful page thy look stir run make folk rest thy thy pain passage nature care sweat darling sake knowing world pas ere enough find heaven stuff clothe heavenly mind

author: SIR PHILIP SIDNEY
content: roses gone sweetened eyes red cheeks oft fair increase frame height honor kindly badge shame hath crimson weeds stolen morning skies doth color made vermilion eyes natures self make self engrained would know right paleness overcame hue whose force heart still unto thraldom ties gales adoption sons beaten way judgement lackey fault sickness lay feeling proof makes say mistake far love makes paper perfect white write therein fresh story delight beauty request ink venus doth stir
poem name: Astrophil and Stella 102: Where be the roses gone, which sweetened so our eyes?
ori_content:
Where be the roses gone, which sweetened so our eyes?
    Where those red cheeks, which oft with fair increase did frame
    The height of honor in the kindly badge of shame?
Who hath the crimson weeds stolen from my morning skies?
How doth the color vade of those vermilion dyes,
    Which Nature's self did make, and self engrained the same!
    I would know by what right this paleness overcame
That hue, whose force my heart still unto thraldom ties?
    Galen's adoptive sons, who by a beaten way
    Their judgements hackney on, the fault on sickness lay;
But feeling proof makes me say they mistake it far:
    It is but love, which makes his paper perfect white
    To write therein more fresh the story of delight,
Whiles beauty's reddest ink Venus for him doth stir.
con: rose gone sweetened eye red cheek oft fair increase frame height honor kindly badge shame hath crimson weed stolen morning sky doth color made vermilion eye nature self make self engrained would know right paleness overcame hue whose force heart still unto thraldom tie gale adoption son beaten way judgement lackey fault sickness lay feeling proof make say mistake far love make paper perfect white write therein fresh story delight beauty request ink venus doth stir

author: SIR PHILIP SIDNEY
content: absent presence still false flattering hope fair face bare hand orphan place still say still appear says thou dainty cheer thou told mine eyes help famished case thou art gone selffelt disgrace doth make wish thy comfort near store fair ladies meet may charm conversation sweet make heavy mould new thoughts grow sure prevail much bade friend new maimed merry think woe
poem name: Astrophil and Stella 106: O absent presence, Stella is not here
ori_content:
O absent presence, Stella is not here;
    False flattering hope, that with so fair a face
    Bare me in hand, that in this orphan place
Stella, I say my Stella, should appear.
What sayst thou now? Where is that dainty cheer
    Thou toldst mine eyes should help their famished case?
    But thou art gone, now that self-felt disgrace
Doth make me most to wish thy comfort near.
    But here I do store of fair ladies meet,
    Who may with charm of conversation sweet
Make in my heavy mould new thoughts to grow:
    Sure they prevail as much with me, as he
    That bade his friend, but then new maimed, to be
Merry with him, and not think of his woe.
con: absent presence still false flattering hope fair face bare hand orphan place still say still appear say thou dainty cheer thou told mine eye help famished case thou art gone selffelt disgrace doth make wish thy comfort near store fair lady meet may charm conversation sweet make heavy mould new thought grow sure prevail much bade friend new maimed merry think woe

author: SIR PHILIP SIDNEY
content: still since thou right princess art powers life bestow ere aught undertaken first resort unto sovereign part sweet give respite heart parts though still leap thee thoughts give thy lieutenant great cause needs use art queen presence sends employs dismiss thee wit till wrought thy attends servants shame oft masters blame doth sit oh let fools thy works reproved scorning say see love
poem name: Astrophil and Stella 107: Stella, since thou so right a princess art
ori_content:
Stella, since thou so right a princess art
Of all the powers which life bestows on me,
There ere by them aught undertaken be
They first resort unto that sovereign part;
Sweet, for a while give respite to my heart,
Which pants as though it still should leap to thee,
And on my thoughts give thy lieutenancy
To this great cause, which needs both use and art,
And as a queen, who from her presence sends
Whom she employs, dismiss from thee my wit,
Till it have wrought what thy own will attends.
On servants shame oft masters blame doth sit.
Oh let not fools in me thy works reprove,
And scorning say, See what it is to love.
con: still since thou right princess art power life bestow ere aught undertaken first resort unto sovereign part sweet give respite heart part though still leap thee thought give thy lieutenant great cause need use art queen presence sends employ dismiss thee wit till wrought thy attends servant shame oft master blame doth sit oh let fool thy work reproved scorning say see love

author: SIR PHILIP SIDNEY
content: alas pain enough friend upon whose breast fierce grip doth tire first stale fire love doth quiver spend rhubarb words must contend grieve worse saying desire doth plunge wellformed soul even sinful thoughts ruin end sin doth manners frame well stayed truth word faith deed ready wit fearing naught shame sin fixed hearts doth breed loathing loose unchastity love sin let sinful
poem name: Astrophil and Stella 14: Alas, have I not pain enough, my friend
ori_content:
Alas, have I not pain enough, my friend,
Upon whose breast a fiercer gripe doth tire
Than did on him who first stale down the fire,
While Love on me doth all his quiver spend,
But with your rhubarb words you must contend
To grieve me worse, in saying that Desire
Doth plunge my well-formed soul even in the mire
Of sinful thoughts, which do in ruin end?
If that be sin which doth the manners frame,
Well stayed with truth in word and faith of deed,
Ready of wit, and fearing naught but shame;
If that be sin which in fixed hearts doth breed
A loathing of all loose unchastity,
Then love is sin, and let me sinful be.
con: ala pain enough friend upon whose breast fierce grip doth tire first stale fire love doth quiver spend rhubarb word must contend grieve worse saying desire doth plunge wellformed soul even sinful thought ruin end sin doth manner frame well stayed truth word faith deed ready wit fearing naught shame sin fixed heart doth breed loathing loose unchastity love sin let sinful

author: SIR PHILIP SIDNEY
content: first sight ribbed shot love gave wound breathe bleed known worth mine time proceed till degrees full conquest got saw liked liked loved loved straight love decreed length loves decrees forced agreed yet reining partial lot even footstep lost liberty gone like slaveborn muscovites call praise suffer tyranny employ remnant wit make believe well feeling skill paint hell
poem name: Astrophil and Stella 2: Not at first sight, nor with a dribbed shot
ori_content:
Not at first sight, nor with a dribbed shot,
   Love gave the wound which while I breathe will bleed:
   But known worth did in mine of time proceed,
Till by degrees it had full conquest got.
I saw, and liked; I liked, but loved not;
   I loved, but straight did not what love decreed:
   At length to loves decrees I, forced, agreed,
Yet with repining at so partial lot.
   Now even that footstep of lost liberty
Is gone, and now like slave-born Muscovite
I call it praise to suffer tyranny;
And now employ the remnant of my wit
   To make myself believe that all is well,
   While with a feeling skill I paint my hell.
con: first sight ribbed shot love gave wound breathe bleed known worth mine time proceed till degree full conquest got saw liked liked loved loved straight love decreed length love decree forced agreed yet reining partial lot even footstep lost liberty gone like slaveborn muscovite call praise suffer tyranny employ remnant wit make believe well feeling skill paint hell

author: SIR PHILIP SIDNEY
content: words friend right healthful caustics blame young mind marred love doth windlass mine writings like bad servants show wits quick vain thoughts virtue lame plato read nought tame polish eyes birth owe nobler desires least else friendly foe great expectation wear train shame since mad march great promise made may years much decline hoped harvest time sure say well wisdom golden mine dig deep learning spade tell hath world ought fair still
poem name: Astrophil and Stella 21: Your words my friend (right healthful caustics) blame
ori_content:
Your words my friend (right healthful caustics) blame
My young mind marred, whom Love doth windlass so,
That mine own writings like bad servants show
My wits, quick in vain thoughts, in virtue lame,
That Plato I read for nought, but if he tame
Such coltish gyres, that to my birth I owe
Nobler desires, least else that friendly foe,
Great expectation, wear a train of shame.
For since mad March great promise made of me,
If now the May of my years much decline,
What can be hoped my harvest time will be?
Sure you say well, your wisdoms golden mine
Dig deep with learnings spade, now tell me this,
Hath this world ought so fair as Stella is?
con: word friend right healthful caustic blame young mind marred love doth windlass mine writing like bad servant show wit quick vain thought virtue lame plato read nought tame polish eye birth owe nobler desire least else friendly foe great expectation wear train shame since mad march great promise made may year much decline hoped harvest time sure say well wisdom golden mine dig deep learning spade tell hath world ought fair still

author: SIR PHILIP SIDNEY
content: wisest scholar wight wise photius doom sugar sentence says virtue met eyes strange flames love souls would raise man pain truth describes thing senses balance weighs behold skies inward sun heroic mind displays virtue late virtuous care stir love takes tells shape mortal eyes might sweetly shine true since see virtues great beauty face prove find effect burn love
poem name: Astrophil and Stella 25: The wisest scholar of the wight most wise
ori_content:
The wisest scholar of the wight most wise
By Phoebus doom, with sugared sentence says
That Virtue, if it once met with our eyes,
Strange flames of love it in our souls would raise;
But, for that man with pain this truth descries,
While he each thing in senses balance weighs,
And so nor will nor can behold those skies
Which inward sun to heroic mind displays,
Virtue of late, with virtuous care to stir
Love of herself, takes Stellas shape, that she
To mortal eyes might sweetly shine in her.
It is most true, for since I her did see,
Virtues great beauty in that face I prove,
And find theffect, for I do burn in love.
con: wisest scholar wight wise photius doom sugar sentence say virtue met eye strange flame love soul would raise man pain truth describes thing sens balance weighs behold sky inward sun heroic mind display virtue late virtuous care stir love take tell shape mortal eye might sweetly shine true since see virtue great beauty face prove find effect burn love

author: SIR PHILIP SIDNEY
content: sad steps moon thou limbs skies silently wan face may even heavenly place busy arched sharp arrows tries sure longwithloveacquainted eyes judge love thou feels lovers case read thy looks thy languished grace feel like thy state describes even fellowship moon tell constant love deemed want wit beauties proud love loved yet lovers scorn love doth possess call virtue thereungratefulness
poem name: Astrophil and Stella 30: With how sad steps, O moon, thou climb'st the skies
ori_content:
With how sad steps, O moon, thou climbst the skies!
How silently, and with how wan a face!
What! may it be that even in heavenly place
That busy archer his sharp arrows tries?
Sure, if that long-with-love-acquainted eyes
Can judge of love, thou feelst a lovers case:
I read it in thy looks; thy languished grace
To me, that feel the like, thy state descries.
Then, even of fellowship, O Moon, tell me,
Is constant love deemed there but want of wit?
Are beauties there as proud as here they be?
Do they above love to be loved, and yet
    Those lovers scorn whom that love doth possess?
    Do they call virtue thereungratefulness?
con: sad step moon thou limb sky silently wan face may even heavenly place busy arched sharp arrow try sure longwithloveacquainted eye judge love thou feel lover case read thy look thy languished grace feel like thy state describes even fellowship moon tell constant love deemed want wit beauty proud love loved yet lover scorn love doth posse call virtue thereungratefulness

author: SIR PHILIP SIDNEY
content: thus betrayed liberty black beams burning marks engraved free side born slave whose neck becomes yoke tyranny want sense feel misery spite disdain disdain long faith though daily help grave may get alms scorn beggary virtue awake beauty beauty may must leave following gain miss let go soft comes go unkind love eye doth make heart give tongue lie
poem name: Astrophil and Stella 47: What, have I thus betrayed my liberty?
ori_content:
What, have I thus betrayed my liberty?
Can those black beams such burning marks engrave
In my free side? or am I born a slave,
Whose neck becomes such yoke of tyranny?
Or want I sense to feel my misery?
Or sprite, disdain of such disdain to have?
Who for long faith, though daily help I crave,
May get no alms but scorn of beggary.
Virtue, awake! Beauty but beauty is;
I may, I must, I can, I will, I do
Leave following that which it is gain to miss.
Let her go. Soft, but here she comes. Go to,
Unkind, I love you not! O me, that eye
Doth make my heart give to my tongue the lie!
con: thus betrayed liberty black beam burning mark engraved free side born slave whose neck becomes yoke tyranny want sense feel misery spite disdain disdain long faith though daily help grave may get alms scorn beggary virtue awake beauty beauty may must leave following gain miss let go soft come go unkind love eye doth make heart give tongue lie

author: SIR PHILIP SIDNEY
content: souls joy bend morning stars virtue made strong beauty might love chastened pain doth learn delight humbleness grows one majesty whatever may ensue let partner riches sight let mine eyes helldrivn light look shine let die see though oft self began heart beams parts gone whose careless wounds even freshly bleed yet since death wound already got dear killer spare sweet cruel shot kind grace slay speed
poem name: Astrophil and Stella 48: Souls joy, bend not those morning stars from me
ori_content:
Souls joy, bend not those morning stars from me,
Where virtue is made strong by beautys might,
Where love is chasteness, pain doth learn delight,
And humbleness grows one with majesty.
Whatever may ensue, O let me be
Co-partner of the riches of that sight;
Let not mine eyes be hell-drivn from that light;
O look, O shine, O let me die and see.
For though I oft my self of them bemoan,
That through my heart their beamy darts be gone,
Whose cureless wounds even now most freshly bleed,
Yet since my death wound is already got,
Dear killer, spare not they sweet cruel shot;
A kind of grace it is to slay with speed.
con: soul joy bend morning star virtue made strong beauty might love chastened pain doth learn delight humbleness grows one majesty whatever may ensue let partner rich sight let mine eye helldrivn light look shine let die see though oft self began heart beam part gone whose careless wound even freshly bleed yet since death wound already got dear killer spare sweet cruel shot kind grace slay speed

author: SIR PHILIP SIDNEY
content: horse love doth try horsemanships strange work prove horseman horse horse love man wrongs poor beast descry reins therewith rider doth tie humbled thoughts bit reverence move curved fear gilt boss hope makes seem fair eye wand thou fancy saddle art girt fast memory spur horse spurs sharp desire heart sits fast however stir hath made hand right manage takes delight
poem name: Astrophil and Stella 49: I on my horse, and Love on me, doth try
ori_content:
I on my horse, and Love on me, doth try
Our horsemanships, while by strange work I prove
A horseman to my horse, a horse to Love,
And now mans wrongs in me, poor beast, descry.
The reins wherewith my rider doth me tie
Are humbled thoughts, which bit of reverence move,
Curbed in with fear, but with gilt boss above
Of hope, which makes it seem fair to the eye.
The wand is will; thou, fancy, saddle art,
Girt fast by memory; and while I spur
My horse, he spurs with sharp desire to my heart;
He sits me fast, however I do stir;
And now hath made me to his hand so right
That in the manage myself takes delight.
con: horse love doth try horsemanship strange work prove horseman horse horse love man wrong poor beast descry rein therewith rider doth tie humbled thought bit reverence move curved fear gilt bos hope make seem fair eye wand thou fancy saddle art girt fast memory spur horse spur sharp desire heart sits fast however stir hath made hand right manage take delight

author: SIR PHILIP SIDNEY
content: true eyes formed serve inward light heavenly part ought king whose rules serve rebels nature strive smart true call copies dart image carve fools adore temple heart till good god make church churchman starve true true beauty virtue indeed whereof beauty shade elements mortal mixture breed true earth pilgrims made soul country move true yet true must still love
poem name: Astrophil and Stella 5: It is most true, that eyes are formed to serve
ori_content:
It is most true, that eyes are formed to serve
The inward light; and that the heavenly part
Ought to be king, from whose rules who do swerve,
Rebels to Nature, strive for their own smart.
    It is most true, what we call Cupids dart,
An image is, which for ourselves we carve;
And, fools, adore in temple of our heart,
Till that good god make Church and churchman starve.
    True, that true beauty virtue is indeed,
Whereof this beauty can be but a shade,
Which elements with mortal mixture breed;
True, that on earth we are but pilgrims made,
    And should in soul up to our country move;
True; and yet true, that I must Stella love.
con: true eye formed serve inward light heavenly part ought king whose rule serve rebel nature strive smart true call copy dart image carve fool adore temple heart till good god make church churchman starve true true beauty virtue indeed whereof beauty shade element mortal mixture breed true earth pilgrim made soul country move true yet true must still love

author: SIR PHILIP SIDNEY
content: strife grown virtue love pretends still must eyes lips faith love since wear badge firmly prove virtue thus title doth improve still dear name still virtuous soul sure heir heavily bliss fair outside hearts doth move therefore though beauty grace loves indeed tells self may pretense claim manner place well love since femur suit doth stay let virtue tells self yet thus let virtue body grant us
poem name: Astrophil and Stella 52: A strife is grown between Virtue and Love
ori_content:
A strife is grown between Virtue and Love,
While each pretends that Stella must be his:
Her eyes, her lips, her all, saith Love, do this,
Since they do wear his badge, most firmly prove.
But Virtue thus that title doth disprove,
That Stella (O dear name) that Stella is
That virtuous soul, sure heir of heavnly bliss;
Not this fair outside, which our hearts doth move.
And therefore, though her beauty and her grace
Be Loves indeed, in Stellas self he may
By no pretense claim any manner place.
Well, Love, since this demur our suit doth stay,
Let Virtue have that Stella's self; yet thus,
Let Virtue but that body grant to us.
con: strife grown virtue love pretend still must eye lip faith love since wear badge firmly prove virtue thus title doth improve still dear name still virtuous soul sure heir heavily bliss fair outside heart doth move therefore though beauty grace love indeed tell self may pretense claim manner place well love since femur suit doth stay let virtue tell self yet thus let virtue body grant u

author: SIR PHILIP SIDNEY
content: grammar rules virtues show children still read awful eyes young dove may precepts wise grant virtue know late heart high eyes low cried thing ever denied lightning love displaying venus skies least heard twice said sing muse pan sing heavens envy high triumphant grammar force sweet success confirm grammar says dear still weigh grammar says grammar says nay one speech two negative affirm
poem name: Astrophil and Stella 63: O Grammar rules, O now your virtues show
ori_content:
O Grammar rules, O now your virtues show;
    So children still read you with awful eyes,
    As my young Dove may in your precepts wise
Her grant to me, by her own virtue know.
For late with heart most high, with eyes most low,
    I cravd the thing which ever she denies:
    She lightning Love, displaying Venus skies,
Least once should not be heard, twice said, No, No.
    Sing then my Muse, now Io Pan sing,
    Heavns envy not at my high triumphing:
But Grammars force with sweet success confirm,
    For Grammar says (O this dear Stella weigh,)
    For Grammar says (to Grammar who says nay)
That in one speech two Negatives affirm.
con: grammar rule virtue show child still read awful eye young dove may precept wise grant virtue know late heart high eye low cried thing ever denied lightning love displaying venus sky least heard twice said sing muse pan sing heaven envy high triumphant grammar force sweet success confirm grammar say dear still weigh grammar say grammar say nay one speech two negative affirm

author: SIR PHILIP SIDNEY
content: desire though thou old companion art oft cling pure love one scarcely descry doth blow fire heart thy fellowship needs must part venus taught dans wings fly must thy sweet passions lie virtues gold must head copies dart service honor wonder delight fear offend worthy appear care shining mine eyes faith spite things let dear thou desire thou couldst banished art yet alas shall
poem name: Astrophil and Stella 72: Desire, though thou my old companion art
ori_content:
Desire, though thou my old companion art,
And oft so clings to my pure Love that I
One from the other scarcely can descry,
While each doth blow the fire of my heart,
Now from thy fellowship I needs must part;
Venus is taught with Dians wings to fly;
I must no more in thy sweet passions lie;
Virtues gold now must head my Cupids dart.
Service and honor, wonder with delight,
Fear to offend, will worthy to appear,
Care shining in mine eyes, faith in my sprite:
These things are let me by my only dear;
But thou, Desire, because thou wouldst have all,
Now banished art. But yet alas how shall?
con: desire though thou old companion art oft cling pure love one scarcely descry doth blow fire heart thy fellowship need must part venus taught dans wing fly must thy sweet passion lie virtue gold must head copy dart service honor wonder delight fear offend worthy appear care shining mine eye faith spite thing let dear thou desire thou couldst banished art yet ala shall

author: SIR PHILIP SIDNEY
content: still think verse seek fame seek hope love live thee thine eyes pride thy lips history thou praise praise shame ambitious frame nest young praise laurel tree truth swear wish grave mine epitaph poets name nay would could title make land thereof grow without plumes others wings take nothing wit doth flow since words thy beauty doth entire love doth hold hand makes write
poem name: Astrophil and Stella 90: Stella, think not that I by verse seek fame
ori_content:
Stella, think not that I by verse seek fame,
Who seek, who hope, who love, who live but thee;
Thine eyes my pride, thy lips my history;
If thou praise not, all other praise is shame.
Nor so ambitious am I, as to frame
A nest for my young praise in laurel tree:
In truth I sweare, I wish not there should be
Graved in mine epitaph a Poets name:
Nay if I would, could I just title make,
That any laud to me thereof should grow,
Without my plumes from others wings I take.
For nothing from my wit or will doth flow,
Since all my words thy beauty doth endite,
And love doth hold my hand, and makes me write.
con: still think verse seek fame seek hope love live thee thine eye pride thy lip history thou praise praise shame ambitious frame nest young praise laurel tree truth swear wish grave mine epitaph poet name nay would could title make land thereof grow without plume others wing take nothing wit doth flow since word thy beauty doth entire love doth hold hand make write

author: GEORGE CHAPMAN
content: come soft rest cares come night come naked virtues tire reaped harvest light bound sheaves sacred fire love calls war sighs alarms lips swords fields arms come night lay thy velvet hand glorious days outraging face thy crowned flames command torches nuptial grace love calls war sighs alarms lips swords field arms
ori_content:
O come, soft rest of cares! come, Night!
       Come, naked Virtues only tire,
The reaped harvest of the light
    Bound up in sheaves of sacred fire,
       Love calls to war:
             Sighs his alarms,
       Lips his swords are,
             The fields his arms.

Come, Night, and lay thy velvet hand
    On glorious Days outfacing face;
And all thy crowned flames command
    For torches to our nuptial grace.
       Love calls to war:
             Sighs his alarms,
       Lips his swords are,
             The field his arms.
con: come soft rest care come night come naked virtue tire reaped harvest light bound sheaf sacred fire love call war sigh alarm lip sword field arm come night lay thy velvet hand glorious day outraging face thy crowned flame command torch nuptial grace love call war sigh alarm lip sword field arm

author: THOMAS CAMPION
content: garden face roses white lilies blow heavenly paradise place wherein pleasant fruits flow theories grow none may buy till cherryripe cry theories fairly enclose orient pearl double row lovely laughter shows look like rosebuds filled snow yet peer prince buy till cherryripe cry eyes like angels watch still brows like bended bows stand threatening piercing frown kill attempt eye hand sacred theories come nigh till cherryripe cry
ori_content:
There is a garden in her face
   Where roses and white lilies blow;
A heavenly paradise is that place,
   Wherein all pleasant fruits do flow:
      There cherries grow which none may buy
      Till Cherry-ripe themselves do cry.

Those cherries fairly do enclose
   Of orient pearl a double row,
Which when her lovely laughter shows,
   They look like rose-buds filled with snow;
      Yet them no peer nor prince can buy
      Till Cherry-ripe themselves do cry.

Her eyes like angels watch them still;
   Her brows like bended bows do stand,
Threat'ning with piercing frowns to kill
   All that attempt with eye or hand
      Those sacred cherries to come nigh,
      Till Cherry-ripe themselves do cry.
con: garden face rose white lily blow heavenly paradise place wherein pleasant fruit flow theory grow none may buy till cherryripe cry theory fairly enclose orient pearl double row lovely laughter show look like rosebud filled snow yet peer prince buy till cherryripe cry eye like angel watch still brow like bended bow stand threatening piercing frown kill attempt eye hand sacred theory come nigh till cherryripe cry

author: ISABELLA WHITNEY
content: time come must depart thee ah famous city never yet rue smart find thou hast pity wherefore small cause grieve thee go many women foolishly like fixed fancy set least deserve long ere wit get away serve time pity oft tell try whether best well utterly defy hath time put mind thy great cruelness never help would find ease distress thou never yet couldst credit give board year apparel relieve except thou played thou never didst good ever wilt know yet angry mood ere go perfect love charity testament write leave thee treasury recite stand aside give leave write latest see none deceive leave till
poem name: A Communication Which the Author Had to London, Before She Made Her Will
ori_content:
The time is come, I must depart
   from thee, ah famous city;
I never yet to rue my smart,
   did find that thou hadst pity.
Wherefore small cause there is, that I
   should grieve from thee to go;
But many women foolishly,
   like me, and other moe,
Do such a fixed fancy set,
   on those which least deserve,
That long it is ere wit we get   
   away from them to swerve.
But time with pity oft will tell   
   to those that will her try,
Whether it best be more to mell,
   or utterly defy.
And now hath time me put in mind
   of thy great cruelness,
That never once a help would find,
   to ease me in distress.
Thou never yet wouldst credit give
   to board me for a year;
Nor with apparel me relieve,
   except thou payed were.
No, no, thou never didst me good,
   nor ever wilt, I know.
Yet am I in no angry mood,
   but will, or ere I go,
In perfect love and charity,
   my testament here write,
And leave to thee such treasury,
   as I in it recite.
Now stand aside and give me leave
      to write my latest will;
And see that none you do deceive
   of that I leave them till.
con: time come must depart thee ah famous city never yet rue smart find thou hast pity wherefore small cause grieve thee go many woman foolishly like fixed fancy set least deserve long ere wit get away serve time pity oft tell try whether best well utterly defy hath time put mind thy great cruelness never help would find ease distress thou never yet couldst credit give board year apparel relieve except thou played thou never didst good ever wilt know yet angry mood ere go perfect love charity testament write leave thee treasury recite stand aside give leave write latest see none deceive leave till

author: HENRY HOWARD, EARL OF SURREY
content: happy dames may embrace fruit delight help bewail useful case eye heavy plight wonted rejoice fortune pleasant choice good ladies help fill mourning voice ship freight remembrance thoughts pleasures past sails hath governance life last scolding sighs lack gale furthering hope sail toward sweet port avail alas oft dreams see eyes food sometime delighted yet good therewith wake return whose absent flame make burn find lack lord mourn lovers arms across rejoice chief delight drowned tears mourn loss stand bitter night window may see winds clouds flee lo marine love hath made green waves salt flood doth rise rage wind thousand fancies mood assail restless mind alas drenched sweet foe spoil heart go left alas seas wax calm chase fro annoy doubtful hope doth cause pain dread cuts joy thus wealth mingled woe thought doubt doth grow comes come alas
poem name: Complaint of the Absence of Her Love Being Upon the Sea
ori_content:
O happy dames, that may embrace
The fruit of your delight,
Help to bewail the woeful case
And eke the heavy plight
Of me, that wonted to rejoice
The fortune of my pleasant choice;
Good ladies, help to fill my mourning voice.

In ship, freight with remembrance
Of thoughts and pleasures past,
He sails that hath in governance
My life while it will last;
With scalding sighs, for lack of gale,
Furthering his hope, that is his sail,
Toward me, the sweet port of his avail.

Alas! how oft in dreams I see
Those eyes that were my food;
Which sometime so delighted me,
That yet they do me good;
Wherewith I wake with his return,
Whose absent flame did make me burn:
But when I find the lack, Lord, how I mourn!

When other lovers in arms across
Rejoice their chief delight.
Drowned in tears, to mourn my loss
I stand the bitter night
In my window, where I may see
Before the winds how the clouds flee.
Lo! what a mariner love hath made of me!

And in green waves when the salt flood
Doth rise by rage of wind,
A thousand fancies in that mood
Assail my restless mind.
Alas! now drencheth my sweet foe,
That with the spoil of my heart did go,
And left me; but, alas! why did he so?

And when the seas wax calm again
To chase fro me annoy,
My doubtful hope doth cause me pain;
So dread cuts off my joy.
Thus is my wealth mingled with woe,
And of each thought a doubt doth grow;
Now he comes! Will he come? Alas, no, no!
con: happy dame may embrace fruit delight help bewail useful case eye heavy plight wonted rejoice fortune pleasant choice good lady help fill mourning voice ship freight remembrance thought pleasure past sail hath governance life last scolding sigh lack gale furthering hope sail toward sweet port avail ala oft dream see eye food sometime delighted yet good therewith wake return whose absent flame make burn find lack lord mourn lover arm across rejoice chief delight drowned tear mourn loss stand bitter night window may see wind cloud flee lo marine love hath made green wave salt flood doth rise rage wind thousand fancy mood assail restless mind ala drenched sweet foe spoil heart go left ala sea wax calm chase fro annoy doubtful hope doth cause pain dread cut joy thus wealth mingled woe thought doubt doth grow come come ala

author: SAMUEL DANIEL
content: unto boundless ocean thy beauty runs poor river charged streams zeal returning thee tribute duty love youth plains reveal clasp book charged soul cast accounts care summed sighs knoll spent thee look look dear expenses youth see reckon thine eyes examine well thy beauty truth cross cares ere greater sum arise read sweet maid though done slightly show love doth love lightly
poem name: Delia 1: Unto the boundless Ocean of thy beauty
ori_content:
Unto the boundless Ocean of thy beauty
Runs this poor river, charged with streams of zeal:
Returning thee the tribute of my duty,
Which here my love, my youth, my plaints reveal.
Here I unclasp the book of my charged soul,
Where I have cast th'accounts of all my care:
Here have I summed my sighs, here I enroll
How they were spent for thee; look what they are.
Look on the dear expenses of my youth,
And see how just I reckon with thine eyes:
Examine well thy beauty with my truth,
And cross my cares ere greater sum arise.
Read it sweet maid, though it be done but slightly;
Who can show all his love, doth love but lightly.
con: unto boundless ocean thy beauty run poor river charged stream zeal returning thee tribute duty love youth plain reveal clasp book charged soul cast account care summed sigh knoll spent thee look look dear expense youth see reckon thine eye examine well thy beauty truth cross care ere greater sum arise read sweet maid though done slightly show love doth love lightly

author: SAMUEL DANIEL
content: go wailing verse infants love minervalike brought forth without mother present image cares prove witness fathers grief exceeds sigh story cruel deeds interrupted accents despair monument whosoever reads may justly praise blame hopeless fair say disdain hath dried blood starved succour still denying press eyes important good waken sleeping pity crying knock hard heart beg till moved tell thinking dearly loved
poem name: Delia 2: Go wailing verse, the infants of my love
ori_content:
Go wailing verse, the infants of my love,
Minerva-like, brought forth without a Mother:
Present the image of the cares I prove,
Witness your Fathers grief exceeds all other.
Sigh out a story of her cruel deeds,
With interrupted accents of despair:
A monument that whosoever reads,
May justly praise, and blame my loveless Fair.
Say her disdain hath dried up my blood,
And starved you, in succours still denying:
Press to her eyes, importune me some good;
Waken her sleeping pity with your crying.
Knock at that hard heart, beg till you have moved her;
And tell thunkind, how dearly I have loved her.
con: go wailing verse infant love minervalike brought forth without mother present image care prove witness father grief exceeds sigh story cruel deed interrupted accent despair monument whosoever read may justly praise blame hopeless fair say disdain hath dried blood starved succour still denying press eye important good waken sleeping pity cry knock hard heart beg till moved tell thinking dearly loved

author: SAMUEL DANIEL
content: love whilst thou mast loved whilst thy may hath filed thy lap flowers whilst thy beauty bears without stain use summer smiles ere winter lowers whilst thou spreads unto rising sun fairest flower ever saw light joy thy time thy sweet done devil think thy morning must night thy brightness sets length west thou wilt close thou chest think becomes fading best shall veil shadow men weigh stalk find flower glory pass
poem name: Delia 32: But love whilst that thou mayst be loved again
ori_content:
But love whilst that thou mayst be loved again,
Now whilst thy May hath filed thy lap with flowers,
Now whilst thy beauty bears without a stain,
Now use the summer smiles, ere winter lowers.
And whilst thou spreadst unto the rising sun
The fairest flower that ever saw the light,
Now joy thy time before thy sweet be done,
And, Delia, think thy morning must have night,
And that thy brightness sets at length to west,
When thou wilt close up that which now thou shewst;
And think the same becomes they fading best
Which then shall most inveil and shadow most.
Men do not weigh the stalk for what it was,
When once they find her flower, her glory, pass.
con: love whilst thou mast loved whilst thy may hath filed thy lap flower whilst thy beauty bear without stain use summer smile ere winter lower whilst thou spread unto rising sun fairest flower ever saw light joy thy time thy sweet done devil think thy morning must night thy brightness set length west thou wilt close thou chest think becomes fading best shall veil shadow men weigh stalk find flower glory pas

ori_content:
But love whilst that thou mayst be loved again,
Now whilst thy May hath filled thy lap with flowers,
Now whilst thy beauty bears without a stain,
Now use the summer smiles, ere winter lowers.
And whilst thou spreadst unto the rising sun
The fairest flower that ever saw the light,
Now joy thy time before thy sweet be done,
And, Delia, think thy morning must have night,
And that thy brightness sets at length to west,
When thou wilt close up that which now thou shewst;

author: SAMUEL DANIEL
content: men shall find thy flower thy glory pass thou careful brow sitting alone received hast message thy glass tells thee truth says gone fresh shalt thou see wounds thou modest though spent thy flame heat remaining loved thee thus thou fades faith shall wax thou art thy waning world shall find miracle fire burn matters spent faith hath thyself shall see thou wast unkind thou mast repent thou mast repent thou hast scorned tears winter snows upon thy golden hairs
poem name: Delia 37: When men shall find thy flower, thy glory pass
ori_content:
When men shall find thy flower, thy glory pass,
And thou, with careful brow sitting alone,
Received hast this message from thy glass,
That tells thee truth, and says that all is gone,
Fresh shalt thou see in me the wounds thou madest,
Though spent thy flame, in me the heat remaining,
I that have loved thee thus before thou fadest,
My faith shall wax, when thou art in thy waning.
The world shall find this miracle in me,
That fire can burn when all the matters spent;
Then what my faith hath been thyself shall see,
And that thou wast unkind thou mayst repent.
Thou mayst repent that thou hast scorned my tears,
When Winter snows upon thy golden hairs.
con: men shall find thy flower thy glory pas thou careful brow sitting alone received hast message thy glass tell thee truth say gone fresh shalt thou see wound thou modest though spent thy flame heat remaining loved thee thus thou fade faith shall wax thou art thy waning world shall find miracle fire burn matter spent faith hath thyself shall see thou wast unkind thou mast repent thou mast repent thou hast scorned tear winter snow upon thy golden hair

author: SAMUEL DANIEL
content: unhappy pen ill accepted papers intimate vain chaste desires chaste desires ever burning tapers kindled eyes celestial fires celestial fires respecting powers deign view glory might humble lines work careful hours sacrifice offer sight since corns rests ill moan self hide wrong content frown infant style cradle grave though self honor get thereby bird sings
poem name: Delia 53: Unhappy pen and ill accepted papers
ori_content:
Unhappy pen and ill accepted papers,
That intimate in vain my chaste desires,
My chaste desires, the ever burning tapers,
Enkindled by her eyes celestial fires.
Celestial fires and unrespecting powers,
That deign not view the glory of your might,
In humble lines the work of careful hours,
The sacrifice I offer to her sight.
But since she scorns her own, this rests for me,
Ill moan my self, and hide the wrong I have:
And so content me that her frowns should be
To my infant style the cradle, and the grave.
What though my self no honor get thereby,
Each bird sings therself, and so will I.
con: unhappy pen ill accepted paper intimate vain chaste desire chaste desire ever burning taper kindled eye celestial fire celestial fire respecting power deign view glory might humble line work careful hour sacrifice offer sight since corn rest ill moan self hide wrong content frown infant style cradle grave though self honor get thereby bird sings

content: face content wondrous well fair lovely behold gladsome cheer grief expel sober looks would speak without words words none tell dress also cried gold wit thus might chance might tied knit knot slide
